Implementation here\n    pass\n```\n\n**Test Pattern (pytest style):**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\ndef test_valid_email_simple():\n    assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\ndef test_invalid_email_no_at():\n    assert validate_email(\"userexample.com\") is False\n```\n\n---\n\n## âœ… Acceptance Criteria\n\n### Core Functionality\n- [ ] Function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` exists in `email_validator.py`\n- [ ] Function returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n- [ ] Function has proper type hints\n\n### Validation Rules (ALL must be enforced)\n- [ ] Exactly one `@` symbol required\n- [ ] Local part (before @) must be 1-64 characters long\n- [ ] Domain part (after @) must be 1-255 characters long\n- [ ] Domain must contain at least one dot (`.`)\n- [ ] No consecutive dots (`..`) allowed anywhere\n- [ ] No leading dot in local part (e.g., `.user@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in local part (e.g., `user.@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No leading dot in domain part (e.g., `user@.example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in domain part (e.g., `user@example.com.` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] Only allowed characters: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n\n### Required Test Cases\n**Must pass (valid emails):**\n- [ ] `user@example.com`\n- [ ] `user.name@domain.co.uk`\n- [ ] `user+tag@example.org`\n\n**Must fail (invalid emails):**\n- [ ] `@example.com` (no local part)\n- [ ] `user@` (no domain)\n- [ ] `user@@example.com` (double @)\n- [ ] `user@.com` (leading dot in domain)\n- [ ] `user@example..com` (consecutive dots)\n\n### Code Quality\n- [ ] Passes `ruff check .` with no errors\n- [ ] Passes `ruff format --check .` with no errors\n- [ ] All pytest tests pass\n- [ ] Code has docstrings explaining the function\n\n---\n\n## âš™ï¸ Implementation Guidance\n\n### Execution Layers\n\n**Layer 0 - Foundation:**\n1. Create `email_validator.py` with the `validate_email` function\n2. Implement all validation rules in order of simplicity\n\n**Layer 1 - Testing:**\n1. Create `test_email_validator.py` with pytest tests\n2. Cover all required valid/invalid cases\n3. Add edge case tests\n\n**Layer 2 - Validation:**\n1. Run `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v`\n2. Run `uv run ruff check .`\n3. Run `uv run ruff format --check .`\n4. Fix any issues\n\n### Implementation Approach\n\n**Recommended validation order (in function):**\n1. Check for exactly one `@` symbol (reject if not)\n2. Split into local and domain parts\n3. Check local part length (1-64)\n4. Check domain part length (1-255)\n5. Check domain has at least one dot\n6. Check no consecutive dots anywhere\n7. Check no leading/trailing dots in local part\n8. Check no leading/trailing dots in domain part\n9. Check all characters are in allowed set\n\n**Character validation:**\n- Allowed in both local and domain: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n- Allowed ONLY in local part: `_`, `%`, `+`\n- The `@` symbol is the separator (already validated)\n\n### Expected Artifacts\n\n| File | Purpose |\n|------|---------|\n| `email_validator.py` | Main module with `validate_email` function |\n| `test_email_validator.py` | Comprehensive pytest test suite |\n\n### Constraints\n- **DO NOT** use external email validation libraries\n- **DO NOT** use `re` module for regex (use string methods for simplicity and clarity)\n- **DO NOT** create additional helper files\n- **DO NOT** over-engineer - keep it simple and readable\n- **DO NOT** add features beyond what's specified\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§ª Testing Guidance\n\n### Test Structure\n```python\n# test_email_validator.py\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n### Required Test Categories\n\n**1. Valid emails (happy path):**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**2. Invalid - structural issues:**\n- `@example.com` - missing local part\n- `user@` - missing domain\n- `user@@example.com` - multiple @ symbols\n- `userexample.com` - no @ symbol\n- Empty string\n\n**3. Invalid - dot issues:**\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `.user@example.com` - leading dot in local\n- `user.@example.com` - trailing dot in local\n- `user@example.com.` - trailing dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots in domain\n- `user..name@example.com` - consecutive dots in local\n\n**4. Invalid - length issues:**\n- Local part > 64 chars\n- Domain part > 255 chars\n- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n\n**5. Invalid - character issues:**\n- `user name@example.com` - space\n- `user@exam ple.com` - space in domain\n- `user!@example.com` - disallowed character\n- `user@example#.com` - disallowed character in domain\n\n**6. Invalid - domain structure:**\n- `user@example` - no dot in domain\n\n### Minimum Test Count\n- At least 3 valid email tests (as specified)\n- At least 5 invalid email tests (as specified)\n- Additional edge case tests recommended\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ” Verification and Traceability\n\n### Pre-Completion Checklist\n\nBefore marking complete, verify:\n\n1. **Files exist:**\n   - 80â†’### Core Functionality\n    81â†’- [ ] Function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` exists in `email_validator.py`\n    82â†’- [ ] Function returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n    83â†’- [ ] Function has proper type hints\n    84â†’\n    85â†’### Validation Rules (ALL must be enforced)\n    86â†’- [ ] Exactly one `@` symbol required\n    87â†’- [ ] Local part (before @) must be 1-64 characters long\n    88â†’- [ ] Domain part (after @) must be 1-255 characters long\n    89â†’- [ ] Domain must contain at least one dot (`.`)\n    90â†’- [ ] No consecutive dots (`..`) allowed anywhere\n    91â†’- [ ] No leading dot in local part (e.g., `.user@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n    92â†’- [ ] No trailing dot in local part (e.g., `user.@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n    93â†’- [ ] No leading dot in domain part (e.g., `user@.example.com` â†’ invalid)\n    94â†’- [ ] No trailing dot in domain part (e.g., `user@example.com.` â†’ invalid)\n    95â†’- [ ] Only allowed characters: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n    96â†’\n    97â†’### Required Test Cases\n    98â†’**Must pass (valid emails):**\n    99â†’- [ ] `user@example.com`\n   100â†’- [ ] `user.name@domain.co.uk`\n   101â†’- [ ] `user+tag@example.org`\n   102â†’\n   103â†’**Must fail (invalid emails):**\n   104â†’- [ ] `@example.com` (no local part)\n   105â†’- [ ] `user@` (no domain)\n   106â†’- [ ] `user@@example.com` (double @)\n   107â†’- [ ] `user@.com` (leading dot in domain)\n   108â†’- [ ] `user@example..com` (consecutive dots)\n   109â†’\n   110â†’### Code Quality\n   111â†’- [ ] Passes `ruff check .` with no errors\n   112â†’- [ ] Passes `ruff format --check .` with no errors\n   113â†’- [ ] All pytest tests pass\n   114â†’- [ ] Code has docstrings explaining the function\n   115â†’\n   116â†’---\n   117â†’\n   118â†’## âš™ï¸ Implementation Guidance\n   119â†’\n   120â†’### Execution Layers\n   121â†’\n   122â†’**Layer 0 - Foundation:**\n   123â†’1. Create `email_validator.py` with the `validate_email` function\n   124â†’2. Implement all validation rules in order of simplicity\n   125â†’\n   126â†’**Layer 1 - Testing:**\n   127â†’1. Create `test_email_validator.py` with pytest tests\n   128â†’2. Cover all required valid/invalid cases\n   129â†’3. Add edge case tests\n   130â†’\n   131â†’**Layer 2 - Validation:**\n   132â†’1. Run `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v`\n   133â†’2. Run `uv run ruff check .`\n   134â†’3. Run `uv run ruff format --check .`\n   135â†’4. Fix any issues\n   136â†’\n   137â†’### Implementation Approach\n   138â†’\n   139â†’**Recommended validation order (in function):**\n   140â†’1. Check for exactly one `@` symbol (reject if not)\n   141â†’2. Split into local and domain parts\n   142â†’3. Check local part length (1-64)\n   143â†’4. Check domain part length (1-255)\n   144â†’5. Check domain has at least one dot\n   145â†’6. Check no consecutive dots anywhere\n   146â†’7. Check no leading/trailing dots in local part\n   147â†’8. Check no leading/trailing dots in domain part\n   148â†’9. Check all characters are in allowed set\n   149â†’\n   150â†’**Character validation:**\n   151â†’- Allowed in both local and domain: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n   152â†’- Allowed ONLY in local part: `_`, `%`, `+`\n   153â†’- The `@` symbol is the separator (already validated)\n   154â†’\n   155â†’### Expected Artifacts\n   156â†’\n   157â†’| File | Purpose |\n   158â†’|------|---------|\n   159â†’| `email_validator.py` | Main module with `validate_email` function |\n   160â†’| `test_email_validator.py` | Comprehensive pytest test suite |\n   161â†’\n   162â†’### Constraints\n   163â†’- **DO NOT** use external email validation libraries\n   164â†’- **DO NOT** use `re` module for regex (use string methods for simplicity and clarity)\n   165â†’- **DO NOT** create additional helper files\n   166â†’- **DO NOT** over-engineer - keep it simple and readable\n   167â†’- **DO NOT** add features beyond what's specified\n   168â†’\n   169â†’---\n   170â†’\n   171â†’## ðŸ§ª Testing Guidance\n   172â†’\n   173â†’### Test Structure\n   174â†’```python\n   175â†’# test_email_validator.py\n   176â†’import pytest\n   177â†’from email_validator import validate_email\n   178â†’\n   179â†’class TestValidEmails:\n   180â†’    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n   181â†’\n   182â†’    def test_simple_email(self):\n   183â†’        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n   184â†’\n   185â†’    # ... more valid cases\n   186â†’\n   187â†’class TestInvalidEmails:\n   188â†’    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n   189â†’\n   190â†’    def test_no_local_part(self):\n   191â†’        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n   192â†’\n   193â†’    # ... more invalid cases\n   194â†’```\n   195â†’\n   196â†’### Required Test Categories\n   197â†’\n   198â†’**1. Valid emails (happy path):**\n   199â†’- `user@example.com` - basic valid\n   200â†’- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n   201â†’- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n   202â†’\n   203â†’**2. Invalid - structural issues:**\n   204â†’- `@example.com` - missing local part\n   205â†’- `user@` - missing domain\n   206â†’- `user@@example.com` - multiple @ symbols\n   207â†’- `userexample.com` - no @ symbol\n   208â†’- Empty string\n   209â†’\n   210â†’**3. Invalid - dot issues:**\n   211â†’- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n   212â†’- `.user@example.com` - leading dot in local\n   213â†’- `user.@example.com` - trailing dot in local\n   214â†’- `user@example.com.` - trailing dot in domain\n   215â†’- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots in domain\n   216â†’- `user..name@example.com` - consecutive dots in local\n   217â†’\n   218â†’**4. Invalid - length issues:**\n   219â†’- Local part > 64 chars\n   220â†’- Domain part > 255 chars\n   221â†’- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n   222â†’- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n   223â†’\n   224â†’**5. Invalid - character issues:**\n   225â†’- `user name@example.com` - space\n   226â†’- `user@exam ple.com` - space in domain\n   227â†’- `user!@example.com` - disallowed character\n   228â†’- `user@example#.com` - disallowed character in domain\n   229â†’\n   230â†’**6. Invalid - domain structure:**\n   231â†’- `user@example` - no dot in domain\n   232â†’\n   233â†’### Minimum Test Count\n   234â†’- At least 3 valid email tests (as specified)\n   235â†’- At least 5 invalid email tests (as specified)\n   236â†’- Additional edge case tests recommended\n   237â†’\n   238â†’---\n   239â†’\n   240â†’## ðŸ” Verification and Traceability\n   241â†’\n   242â†’### Pre-Completion Checklist\n   243â†’\n   244â†’Before marking complete, verify:\n   245â†’\n   246â†’1. **Files exist:**\n   247â†’   - [ ] `email_validator.py` created in project root\n   248â†’   - [ ] `test_email_validator.py` created in project root\n   249â†’\n   250â†’2. **Tests pass:**\n   251â†’   ```bash\n   252â†’   uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\n   253â†’   ```\n   254â†’   - this is a greenfield implementation\n- **No existing code patterns** to follow - this is a standalone benchmark task\n\n### Environment Notes\n- Use `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v` to run tests\n- Use `uv run ruff check .` and `uv run ruff format --check .` for linting\n- Commit after creating/modifying files\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§© Related Code Context\n\nThis is a standalone task with no related codebase. However, for reference:\n\n**Email Validation Pattern (example approach):**\n```python\ndef validate_email(email: str) -> bool:\n    \"\"\"Validate email address according to specified rules.\n\n    Args:\n        email: The email address to validate.\n\n    Returns:\n        True if valid, False otherwise.\n    \"\"\"\n    # Implementation here\n    pass\n```\n\n**Test Pattern (pytest style):**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\ndef test_valid_email_simple():\n    assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\ndef test_invalid_email_no_at():\n    assert validate_email(\"userexample.com\") is False\n```\n\n---\n\n## âœ… Acceptance Criteria\n\n### Core Functionality\n- [ ] Function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` exists in `email_validator.py`\n- [ ] Function returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n- [ ] Function has proper type hints\n\n### Validation Rules (ALL must be enforced)\n- [ ] Exactly one `@` symbol required\n- [ ] Local part (before @) must be 1-64 characters long\n- [ ] Domain part (after @) must be 1-255 characters long\n- [ ] Domain must contain at least one dot (`.`)\n- [ ] No consecutive dots (`..`) allowed anywhere\n- [ ] No leading dot in local part (e.g., `.user@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in local part (e.g., `user.@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No leading dot in domain part (e.g., `user@.example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in domain part (e.g., `user@example.com.` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] Only allowed characters: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n\n### Required Test Cases\n**Must pass (valid emails):**\n- [ ] `user@example.com`\n- [ ] `user.name@domain.co.uk`\n- [ ] `user+tag@example.org`\n\n**Must fail (invalid emails):**\n- [ ] `@example.com` (no local part)\n- [ ] `user@` (no domain)\n- [ ] `user@@example.com` (double @)\n- [ ] `user@.com` (leading dot in domain)\n- [ ] `user@example..com` (consecutive dots)\n\n### Code Quality\n- [ ] Passes `ruff check .` with no errors\n- [ ] Passes `ruff format --check .` with no errors\n- [ ] All pytest tests pass\n- [ ] Code has docstrings explaining the function\n\n---\n\n## âš™ï¸ Implementation Guidance\n\n### Execution Layers\n\n**Layer 0 - Foundation:**\n1. Create `email_validator.py` with the `validate_email` function\n2. Implement all validation rules in order of simplicity\n\n**Layer 1 - Testing:**\n1. Create `test_email_validator.py` with pytest tests\n2. Cover all required valid/invalid cases\n3. Add edge case tests\n\n**Layer 2 - Validation:**\n1. Run `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v`\n2. Run `uv run ruff check .`\n3. Run `uv run ruff format --check .`\n4. Fix any issues\n\n### Implementation Approach\n\n**Recommended validation order (in function):**\n1. Check for exactly one `@` symbol (reject if not)\n2. Split into local and domain parts\n3. Check local part length (1-64)\n4. Check domain part length (1-255)\n5. Check domain has at least one dot\n6. Check no consecutive dots anywhere\n7. Check no leading/trailing dots in local part\n8. Check no leading/trailing dots in domain part\n9. Check all characters are in allowed set\n\n**Character validation:**\n- Allowed in both local and domain: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n- Allowed ONLY in local part: `_`, `%`, `+`\n- The `@` symbol is the separator (already validated)\n\n### Expected Artifacts\n\n| File | Purpose |\n|------|---------|\n| `email_validator.py` | Main module with `validate_email` function |\n| `test_email_validator.py` | Comprehensive pytest test suite |\n\n### Constraints\n- **DO NOT** use external email validation libraries\n- **DO NOT** use `re` module for regex (use string methods for simplicity and clarity)\n- **DO NOT** create additional helper files\n- **DO NOT** over-engineer - keep it simple and readable\n- **DO NOT** add features beyond what's specified\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§ª Testing Guidance\n\n### Test Structure\n```python\n# test_email_validator.py\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n### Required Test Categories\n\n**1. Valid emails (happy path):**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**2. Invalid - structural issues:**\n- `@example.com` - missing local part\n- `user@` - missing domain\n- `user@@example.com` - multiple @ symbols\n- `userexample.com` - no @ symbol\n- Empty string\n\n**3. Invalid - dot issues:**\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `.user@example.com` - leading dot in local\n- `user.@example.com` - trailing dot in local\n- `user@example.com.` - trailing dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots in domain\n- `user..name@example.com` - consecutive dots in local\n\n**4. Invalid - length issues:**\n- Local part > 64 chars\n- Domain part > 255 chars\n- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n\n**5. Invalid - character issues:**\n- `user name@example.com` - space\n- `user@exam ple.com` - space in domain\n- `user!@example.com` - disallowed character\n- `user@example#.com` - disallowed character in domain\n\n**6. Invalid - domain structure:**\n- `user@example` - no dot in domain\n\n### Minimum Test Count\n- At least 3 valid email tests (as specified)\n- At least 5 invalid email tests (as specified)\n- Additional edge case tests recommended\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ” Verification and Traceability\n\n### Pre-Completion Checklist\n\nBefore marking complete, verify:\n\n1. **Files exist:**\n   - [ ] `email_validator.py` created in project root\n   - [ ] `test_email_validator.py` created in project root\n\n2. **Tests pass:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\n   ```\n   - [ ] All tests pass (0 failures)\n\n3. **Linting passes:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run ruff check .\n   uv run ruff format --check .\n   ```\n   - [ ] No ruff errors\n   - [ ] No formatting issues\n\n4. **Manual spot check:**\n   ```python\n   from email_validator import validate_email\n   assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") == True\n   assert validate_email(\"invalid\") == False\n   ```\n\n5. **Git commit:**\n   - Use only Python stdlib - no external libraries and no regex.\n\n**Validation Rules to Implement (in order):**\n1. Exactly one `@` symbol required\n2. Split into local part (before @) and domain part (after @)\n3. Local part must be 1-64 characters\n4. Domain part must be 1-255 characters\n5. Domain must contain at least one dot (`.`)\n6. No consecutive dots (`..`) anywhere in the email\n7. No leading dot in local part (e.g., `.user@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n8. No trailing dot in local part (e.g., `user.@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n9. No leading dot in domain part (e.g., `user@.example.com` â†’ invalid)\n10. No trailing dot in domain part (e.g., `user@example.com.` â†’ invalid)\n11. Only allowed characters:\n    - Local part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n    - Domain part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n\n**Expected Function Signature:**\n```python\ndef validate_email(email: str) -> bool:\n    \"\"\"Validate email address according to specified rules.\n\n    Args:\n        email: The email address to validate.\n\n    Returns:\n        True if valid, False otherwise.\n    \"\"\"\n```\n\nAfter implementation, verify with:\n```bash\nuv run ruff check email_validator.py\nuv run ruff format --check email_validator.py\n```\n\n## COMPLEXITY\nLow\n\n## CONTEXT REFERENCE\n**For complete environment context, read:**\n- `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/.claudiomiro/AI_PROMPT.md` - {"type":"assistant","message":{"model":"claude-opus-4-5-20251101","id":"msg_01CGwc613u7zeG3fMPELRHYc","type":"message","role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"tool_use","id":"toolu_014rSC9Lj9f927Zf5NF13Mwr","name":"Write","input":{"file_path":"/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/.claudiomiro/TASK2/PROMPT.md","content":"## PROMPT\nCreate `test_email_validator.py` with a comprehensive pytest test suite for the `validate_email` function. Cover all specified valid emails, invalid emails, and edge cases.\n\n**Required Test Structure:**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n**Required Valid Email Tests:**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid email\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**Required Invalid Email Tests (minimum):**\n- `@example.com` - no local part\n- `user@` - no domain\n- `user@@example.com` - double @\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots\n\n**Additional Edge Cases to Cover:**\n- Empty string\n- No @ symbol (`userexample.com`)\n- Leading dot in local (`.user@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in local (`user.@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in domain (`user@example.com.`)\n- Consecutive dots in local (`user..name@example.com`)\n- Local part > 64 characters\n- Domain part > 255 characters\n- Space in local part\n- Space in domain\n- Disallowed character in local (`user!@example.com`)\n- Disallowed character in domain (`user@example#.com`)\n- No dot in domain (`user@example`)\n\nAfter implementation, verify with:\n```bash\nuv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\nuv run ruff check test_email_validator.py\nuv run ruff format --check test_email_validator.py\n```\n\n## COMPLEXITY\nLow\n\n## CONTEXT REFERENCE\n**For complete environment context, read:**\n- `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/.claudiomiro/AI_PROMPT.md` - Valid emails (happy path) - should return True\n2. Invalid - structural issues - missing parts, multiple @\n3. Invalid - dot issues - leading, trailing, consecutive\n4. Invalid - length issues - too long local/domain\n5. Invalid - character issues - spaces, disallowed chars\n6. Invalid - domain structure - no dot in domain\n\n**Length Test Data:**\n- Local > 64: `\"a\" * 65 + \"@example.com\"`\n- Domain > 255: `\"user@\" + \"a\" * 252 + \".com\"` (256 chars after @)\n\n## LAYER\n1\n\n## PARALLELIZATION\nParallel with: None (depends on TASK1)\n\n## CONSTRAINTS\n- IMPORTANT: Do not perform any git commit or git push.\n- Must import from `email_validator` module (TASK1)\n- Use pytest style (not unittest)\n- Use test classes for organization\n- Each test should be atomic and independent\n- Verify with ruff check and ruff format before completion\n- Run pytest to confirm all tests pass\n"}}],"stop_reason":"tool_use","stop_sequence":null,"usage":{"input_tokens":1,"cache_creation_input_tokens":1083,"cache_read_input_tokens":37262,"cache_creation":{"ephemeral_5m_input_tokens":1083,"ephemeral_1h_input_tokens":0},"output_tokens":1162,"service_tier":"standard"},"context_management":{"applied_edits":[]}},"parent_tool_use_id":null,"session_id":"2f6b2100-c8c7-48d4-9fbd-7eeeced5ca2b","uuid":"5ad8f5ff-4fbc-48b3-a306-c0434d543eb8"}

Cover all specified valid emails, invalid emails, and edge cases.\n\n**Required Test Structure:**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n**Required Valid Email Tests:**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid email\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**Required Invalid Email Tests (minimum):**\n- `@example.com` - no local part\n- `user@` - no domain\n- `user@@example.com` - double @\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots\n\n**Additional Edge Cases to Cover:**\n- Empty string\n- No @ symbol (`userexample.com`)\n- Leading dot in local (`.user@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in local (`user.@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in domain (`user@example.com.`)\n- Consecutive dots in local (`user..name@example.com`)\n- Local part > 64 characters\n- Domain part > 255 characters\n- Space in local part\n- Space in domain\n- Disallowed character in local (`user!@example.com`)\n- Disallowed character in domain (`user@example#.com`)\n- No dot in domain (`user@example`)\n\nAfter implementation, verify with:\n```bash\nuv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\nuv run ruff check test_email_validator.py\nuv run ruff format --check test_email_validator.py\n```\n\n## COMPLEXITY\nLow\n\n## CONTEXT REFERENCE\n**For complete environment context, read:**\n- `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/.claudiomiro/AI_PROMPT.md` - Valid emails (happy path) - should return True\n2. Invalid - structural issues - missing parts, multiple @\n3. Invalid - dot issues - leading, trailing, consecutive\n4. Invalid - length issues - too long local/domain\n5. Invalid - character issues - spaces, disallowed chars\n6. Invalid - domain structure - no dot in domain\n\n**Length Test Data:**\n- Local > 64: `\"a\" * 65 + \"@example.com\"`\n- Domain > 255: `\"user@\" + \"a\" * 252 + \".com\"` (256 chars after @)\n\n## LAYER\n1\n\n## PARALLELIZATION\nParallel with: None (depends on TASK1)\n\n## CONSTRAINTS\n- IMPORTANT: Do not perform any git commit or git push.\n- Must import from `email_validator` module (TASK1)\n- Use pytest style (not unittest)\n- Use test classes for organization\n- Each test should be atomic and independent\n- Verify with ruff check and ruff format before completion\n- Run pytest to confirm all tests pass\n","structuredPatch":[],"originalFile":null}}

However, for reference:\n\n**Email Validation Pattern (example approach):**\n```python\ndef validate_email(email: str) -> bool:\n    \"\"\"Validate email address according to specified rules.\n\n    Args:\n        email: The email address to validate.\n\n    Returns:\n        True if valid, False otherwise.\n    \"\"\"\n    # Implementation here\n    pass\n```\n\n**Test Pattern (pytest style):**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\ndef test_valid_email_simple():\n    assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\ndef test_invalid_email_no_at():\n    assert validate_email(\"userexample.com\") is False\n```\n\n---\n\n## âœ… Acceptance Criteria\n\n### Core Functionality\n- [ ] Function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` exists in `email_validator.py`\n- [ ] Function returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n- [ ] Function has proper type hints\n\n### Validation Rules (ALL must be enforced)\n- [ ] Exactly one `@` symbol required\n- [ ] Local part (before @) must be 1-64 characters long\n- [ ] Domain part (after @) must be 1-255 characters long\n- [ ] Domain must contain at least one dot (`.`)\n- [ ] No consecutive dots (`..`) allowed anywhere\n- [ ] No leading dot in local part (e.g., `.user@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in local part (e.g., `user.@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No leading dot in domain part (e.g., `user@.example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in domain part (e.g., `user@example.com.` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] Only allowed characters: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n\n### Required Test Cases\n**Must pass (valid emails):**\n- [ ] `user@example.com`\n- [ ] `user.name@domain.co.uk`\n- [ ] `user+tag@example.org`\n\n**Must fail (invalid emails):**\n- [ ] `@example.com` (no local part)\n- [ ] `user@` (no domain)\n- [ ] `user@@example.com` (double @)\n- [ ] `user@.com` (leading dot in domain)\n- [ ] `user@example..com` (consecutive dots)\n\n### Code Quality\n- [ ] Passes `ruff check .` with no errors\n- [ ] Passes `ruff format --check .` with no errors\n- [ ] All pytest tests pass\n- [ ] Code has docstrings explaining the function\n\n---\n\n## âš™ï¸ Implementation Guidance\n\n### Execution Layers\n\n**Layer 0 - Foundation:**\n1. Create `email_validator.py` with the `validate_email` function\n2. Implement all validation rules in order of simplicity\n\n**Layer 1 - Testing:**\n1. Create `test_email_validator.py` with pytest tests\n2. Cover all required valid/invalid cases\n3. Add edge case tests\n\n**Layer 2 - Validation:**\n1. Run `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v`\n2. Run `uv run ruff check .`\n3. Run `uv run ruff format --check .`\n4. Fix any issues\n\n### Implementation Approach\n\n**Recommended validation order (in function):**\n1. Check for exactly one `@` symbol (reject if not)\n2. Split into local and domain parts\n3. Check local part length (1-64)\n4. Check domain part length (1-255)\n5. Check domain has at least one dot\n6. Check no consecutive dots anywhere\n7. Check no leading/trailing dots in local part\n8. Check no leading/trailing dots in domain part\n9. Check all characters are in allowed set\n\n**Character validation:**\n- Allowed in both local and domain: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n- Allowed ONLY in local part: `_`, `%`, `+`\n- The `@` symbol is the separator (already validated)\n\n### Expected Artifacts\n\n| File | Purpose |\n|------|---------|\n| `email_validator.py` | Main module with `validate_email` function |\n| `test_email_validator.py` | Comprehensive pytest test suite |\n\n### Constraints\n- **DO NOT** use external email validation libraries\n- **DO NOT** use `re` module for regex (use string methods for simplicity and clarity)\n- **DO NOT** create additional helper files\n- **DO NOT** over-engineer - keep it simple and readable\n- **DO NOT** add features beyond what's specified\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§ª Testing Guidance\n\n### Test Structure\n```python\n# test_email_validator.py\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n### Required Test Categories\n\n**1. Valid emails (happy path):**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**2. Invalid - structural issues:**\n- `@example.com` - missing local part\n- `user@` - missing domain\n- `user@@example.com` - multiple @ symbols\n- `userexample.com` - no @ symbol\n- Empty string\n\n**3. Invalid - dot issues:**\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `.user@example.com` - leading dot in local\n- `user.@example.com` - trailing dot in local\n- `user@example.com.` - trailing dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots in domain\n- `user..name@example.com` - consecutive dots in local\n\n**4. Invalid - length issues:**\n- Local part > 64 chars\n- Domain part > 255 chars\n- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n\n**5. Invalid - character issues:**\n- `user name@example.com` - space\n- `user@exam ple.com` - space in domain\n- `user!@example.com` - disallowed character\n- `user@example#.com` - disallowed character in domain\n\n**6. Invalid - domain structure:**\n- `user@example` - no dot in domain\n\n### Minimum Test Count\n- At least 3 valid email tests (as specified)\n- At least 5 invalid email tests (as specified)\n- Additional edge case tests recommended\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ” Verification and Traceability\n\n### Pre-Completion Checklist\n\nBefore marking complete, verify:\n\n1. **Files exist:**\n   - However, for reference:\n\n**Email Validation Pattern (example approach):**\n```python\ndef validate_email(email: str) -> bool:\n    \"\"\"Validate email address according to specified rules.\n\n    Args:\n        email: The email address to validate.\n\n    Returns:\n        True if valid, False otherwise.\n    \"\"\"\n    # Implementation here\n    pass\n```\n\n**Test Pattern (pytest style):**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\ndef test_valid_email_simple():\n    assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\ndef test_invalid_email_no_at():\n    assert validate_email(\"userexample.com\") is False\n```\n\n---\n\n## âœ… Acceptance Criteria\n\n### Core Functionality\n- [ ] Function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` exists in `email_validator.py`\n- [ ] Function returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n- [ ] Function has proper type hints\n\n### Validation Rules (ALL must be enforced)\n- [ ] Exactly one `@` symbol required\n- [ ] Local part (before @) must be 1-64 characters long\n- [ ] Domain part (after @) must be 1-255 characters long\n- [ ] Domain must contain at least one dot (`.`)\n- [ ] No consecutive dots (`..`) allowed anywhere\n- [ ] No leading dot in local part (e.g., `.user@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in local part (e.g., `user.@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No leading dot in domain part (e.g., `user@.example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in domain part (e.g., `user@example.com.` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] Only allowed characters: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n\n### Required Test Cases\n**Must pass (valid emails):**\n- [ ] `user@example.com`\n- [ ] `user.name@domain.co.uk`\n- [ ] `user+tag@example.org`\n\n**Must fail (invalid emails):**\n- [ ] `@example.com` (no local part)\n- [ ] `user@` (no domain)\n- [ ] `user@@example.com` (double @)\n- [ ] `user@.com` (leading dot in domain)\n- [ ] `user@example..com` (consecutive dots)\n\n### Code Quality\n- [ ] Passes `ruff check .` with no errors\n- [ ] Passes `ruff format --check .` with no errors\n- [ ] All pytest tests pass\n- [ ] Code has docstrings explaining the function\n\n---\n\n## âš™ï¸ Implementation Guidance\n\n### Execution Layers\n\n**Layer 0 - Foundation:**\n1. Create `email_validator.py` with the `validate_email` function\n2. Implement all validation rules in order of simplicity\n\n**Layer 1 - Testing:**\n1. Create `test_email_validator.py` with pytest tests\n2. Cover all required valid/invalid cases\n3. Add edge case tests\n\n**Layer 2 - Validation:**\n1. Run `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v`\n2. Run `uv run ruff check .`\n3. Run `uv run ruff format --check .`\n4. Fix any issues\n\n### Implementation Approach\n\n**Recommended validation order (in function):**\n1. Check for exactly one `@` symbol (reject if not)\n2. Split into local and domain parts\n3. Check local part length (1-64)\n4. Check domain part length (1-255)\n5. Check domain has at least one dot\n6. Check no consecutive dots anywhere\n7. Check no leading/trailing dots in local part\n8. Check no leading/trailing dots in domain part\n9. Check all characters are in allowed set\n\n**Character validation:**\n- Allowed in both local and domain: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n- Allowed ONLY in local part: `_`, `%`, `+`\n- The `@` symbol is the separator (already validated)\n\n### Expected Artifacts\n\n| File | Purpose |\n|------|---------|\n| `email_validator.py` | Main module with `validate_email` function |\n| `test_email_validator.py` | Comprehensive pytest test suite |\n\n### Constraints\n- **DO NOT** use external email validation libraries\n- **DO NOT** use `re` module for regex (use string methods for simplicity and clarity)\n- **DO NOT** create additional helper files\n- **DO NOT** over-engineer - keep it simple and readable\n- **DO NOT** add features beyond what's specified\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§ª Testing Guidance\n\n### Test Structure\n```python\n# test_email_validator.py\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n### Required Test Categories\n\n**1. Valid emails (happy path):**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**2. Invalid - structural issues:**\n- `@example.com` - missing local part\n- `user@` - missing domain\n- `user@@example.com` - multiple @ symbols\n- `userexample.com` - no @ symbol\n- Empty string\n\n**3. Invalid - dot issues:**\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `.user@example.com` - leading dot in local\n- `user.@example.com` - trailing dot in local\n- `user@example.com.` - trailing dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots in domain\n- `user..name@example.com` - consecutive dots in local\n\n**4. Invalid - length issues:**\n- Local part > 64 chars\n- Domain part > 255 chars\n- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n\n**5. Invalid - character issues:**\n- `user name@example.com` - space\n- `user@exam ple.com` - space in domain\n- `user!@example.com` - disallowed character\n- `user@example#.com` - disallowed character in domain\n\n**6. Invalid - domain structure:**\n- `user@example` - no dot in domain\n\n### Minimum Test Count\n- At least 3 valid email tests (as specified)\n- At least 5 invalid email tests (as specified)\n- Additional edge case tests recommended\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ” Verification and Traceability\n\n### Pre-Completion Checklist\n\nBefore marking complete, verify:\n\n1. **Files exist:**\n   - [ ] `email_validator.py` created in project root\n   - [ ] `test_email_validator.py` created in project root\n\n2. **Tests pass:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\n   ```\n   - [ ] All tests pass (0 failures)\n\n3. **Linting passes:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run ruff check .\n   uv run ruff format --check .\n   ```\n   - [ ] No ruff errors\n   - [ ] No formatting issues\n\n4. **Manual spot check:**\n   ```python\n   from email_validator import validate_email\n   assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") == True\n   assert validate_email(\"invalid\") == False\n   ```\n\n5. **Git commit:**\n   - [ ] Changes committed to `task/t1-email-validator` branch\n\n### Requirement Traceability\n\n| Original Requirement | Implementation Location |\n|---------------------|------------------------|\n| Function signature | `email_validator.py` - function definition |\n| Exactly one @ | Validation step in function |\n| Local part 1-64 chars | Validation step in function |\n| Domain part 1-255 chars | Validation step in function |\n| Domain has dot | Validation step in function |\n| No consecutive dots | Validation step in function |\n| No leading/trailing dots | Validation step in function |\n| Allowed characters only | Validation step in function |\n| Valid test cases | `test_email_validator.py` - TestValidEmails |\n| Invalid test cases | `test_email_validator.py` - TestInvalidEmails |\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§  Reasoning Boundaries\n\n### Keep It Simple\n- This is a trivial complexity task - don't over-engineer\n- Use simple string methods, not regex\n- One function, one file, one test file\n- No need for classes in the main module (just a function)\n\n### Don't Add\n- Command-line interfaces\n- Additional validation beyond what's specified\n- Custom exceptions (just return bool)\n- Logging\n- Configuration options\n- Additional helper functions (unless truly necessary for readability)\n\n### Decision Points\n- If unsure whether a character is \"allowed\", refer to the spec: `a-z, A-Z, 0-9, . _ % + -`\n- If unsure about edge cases not covered in tests, implement the safest interpretation that follows the rules\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ“‹ Summary\n\n**Create two files:**\n\n1. **`email_validator.py`** containing:\n   - `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` function\n   - Implements all 8 validation rules\n   - Uses only stdlib (no external deps)\n   - Clean, documented code\n\n2. **`test_email_validator.py`** containing:\n   - pytest tests for all specified valid emails\n   - pytest tests for all specified invalid emails\n   - Additional edge case coverage\n\n**Verify with:**\n```bash\nuv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\nuv run ruff check .\nuv run ruff format --check .\n```\n\n**Commit when complete.**\n","numLines":336,"startLine":1,"totalLines":336}}}

basic valid email\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**Required Invalid Email Tests (minimum):**\n- `@example.com` - no local part\n- `user@` - no domain\n- `user@@example.com` - double @\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots\n\n**Additional Edge Cases to Cover:**\n- Empty string\n- No @ symbol (`userexample.com`)\n- Leading dot in local (`.user@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in local (`user.@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in domain (`user@example.com.`)\n- Consecutive dots in local (`user..name@example.com`)\n- Local part > 64 characters\n- Domain part > 255 characters\n- Space in local part\n- Space in domain\n- Disallowed character in local (`user!@example.com`)\n- Disallowed character in domain (`user@example#.com`)\n- No dot in domain (`user@example`)\n\nAfter implementation, verify with:\n```bash\nuv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\nuv run ruff check test_email_validator.py\nuv run ruff format --check test_email_validator.py\n```\n\n## COMPLEXITY\nLow\n\n## CONTEXT REFERENCE\n**For complete environment context, read:**\n- `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/.claudiomiro/AI_PROMPT.md` - Contains full tech stack, test patterns (lines 174-194), required test cases (lines 198-229)\n\n**You MUST read AI_PROMPT.md before executing this task to understand the environment.**\n\n## TASK-SPECIFIC CONTEXT\n\n### Files This Task Will Touch\n- CREATE: `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/test_email_validator.py`\n\n### Patterns to Follow\n- Test class structure from AI_PROMPT.md (lines 174-194)\n- pytest style assertions: `assert ... is True`, `assert ... is False`\n- Test method naming: `test_<descriptive_name>`\n\n### Integration Points\n- Imports `validate_email` from `email_validator` (created in TASK1)\n- Run with `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v`\n\n## EXTRA DOCUMENTATION\n\n**Test Categories:**\n1. Valid emails (happy path) - should return True\n2. Invalid - structural issues - missing parts, multiple @\n3. Invalid - dot issues - leading, trailing, consecutive\n4. Invalid - length issues - too long local/domain\n5. Invalid - character issues - spaces, disallowed chars\n6. Invalid - domain structure - no dot in domain\n\n**Length Test Data:**\n- Local > 64: `\"a\" * 65 + \"@example.com\"`\n- Domain > 255: `\"user@\" + \"a\" * 252 + \".com\"` (256 chars after @)\n\n## LAYER\n1\n\n## PARALLELIZATION\nParallel with: None (depends on TASK1)\n\n## CONSTRAINTS\n- IMPORTANT: Do not perform any git commit or git push.\n- Must import from `email_validator` module (TASK1)\n- Use pytest style (not unittest)\n- Use test classes for organization\n- Each test should be atomic and independent\n- Verify with ruff check and ruff format before completion\n- Run pytest to confirm all tests pass\n","numLines":113,"startLine":1,"totalLines":113}}}

Create `email_validator.py` with the `validate_email` function\n2. Implement all validation rules in order of simplicity\n\n**Layer 1 - Testing:**\n1. Create `test_email_validator.py` with pytest tests\n2. Cover all required valid/invalid cases\n3. Add edge case tests\n\n**Layer 2 - Validation:**\n1. Run `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v`\n2. Run `uv run ruff check .`\n3. Run `uv run ruff format --check .`\n4. Fix any issues\n\n### Implementation Approach\n\n**Recommended validation order (in function):**\n1. Check for exactly one `@` symbol (reject if not)\n2. Split into local and domain parts\n3. Check local part length (1-64)\n4. Check domain part length (1-255)\n5. Check domain has at least one dot\n6. Check no consecutive dots anywhere\n7. Check no leading/trailing dots in local part\n8. Check no leading/trailing dots in domain part\n9. Check all characters are in allowed set\n\n**Character validation:**\n- Allowed in both local and domain: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n- Allowed ONLY in local part: `_`, `%`, `+`\n- The `@` symbol is the separator (already validated)\n\n### Expected Artifacts\n\n| File | Purpose |\n|------|---------|\n| `email_validator.py` | Main module with `validate_email` function |\n| `test_email_validator.py` | Comprehensive pytest test suite |\n\n### Constraints\n- **DO NOT** use external email validation libraries\n- **DO NOT** use `re` module for regex (use string methods for simplicity and clarity)\n- **DO NOT** create additional helper files\n- **DO NOT** over-engineer - keep it simple and readable\n- **DO NOT** add features beyond what's specified\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§ª Testing Guidance\n\n### Test Structure\n```python\n# test_email_validator.py\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n### Required Test Categories\n\n**1. Valid emails (happy path):**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**2. Invalid - structural issues:**\n- `@example.com` - missing local part\n- `user@` - missing domain\n- `user@@example.com` - multiple @ symbols\n- `userexample.com` - no @ symbol\n- Empty string\n\n**3. Invalid - dot issues:**\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `.user@example.com` - leading dot in local\n- `user.@example.com` - trailing dot in local\n- `user@example.com.` - trailing dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots in domain\n- `user..name@example.com` - consecutive dots in local\n\n**4. Invalid - length issues:**\n- Local part > 64 chars\n- Domain part > 255 chars\n- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n\n**5. Invalid - character issues:**\n- `user name@example.com` - space\n- `user@exam ple.com` - space in domain\n- `user!@example.com` - disallowed character\n- `user@example#.com` - disallowed character in domain\n\n**6. Invalid - domain structure:**\n- `user@example` - no dot in domain\n\n### Minimum Test Count\n- At least 3 valid email tests (as specified)\n- At least 5 invalid email tests (as specified)\n- Additional edge case tests recommended\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ” Verification and Traceability\n\n### Pre-Completion Checklist\n\nBefore marking complete, verify:\n\n1. **Files exist:**\n   - [ ] `email_validator.py` created in project root\n   - [ ] `test_email_validator.py` created in project root\n\n2. **Tests pass:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\n   ```\n   - [ ] All tests pass (0 failures)\n\n3. **Linting passes:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run ruff check .\n   uv run ruff format --check .\n   ```\n   - [ ] No ruff errors\n   - [ ] No formatting issues\n\n4. **Manual spot check:**\n   ```python\n   from email_validator import validate_email\n   assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") == True\n   assert validate_email(\"invalid\") == False\n   ```\n\n5. **Git commit:**\n   - [ ] Changes committed to `task/t1-email-validator` branch\n\n### Requirement Traceability\n\n| Original Requirement | Implementation Location |\n|---------------------|------------------------|\n| Function signature | `email_validator.py` - function definition |\n| Exactly one @ | Validation step in function |\n| Local part 1-64 chars | Validation step in function |\n| Domain part 1-255 chars | Validation step in function |\n| Domain has dot | Validation step in function |\n| No consecutive dots | Validation step in function |\n| No leading/trailing dots | Validation step in function |\n| Allowed characters only | Validation step in function |\n| Valid test cases | `test_email_validator.py` - TestValidEmails |\n| Invalid test cases | `test_email_validator.py` - TestInvalidEmails |\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§  Reasoning Boundaries\n\n### Keep It Simple\n- This is a trivial complexity task - don't over-engineer\n- Use simple string methods, not regex\n- One function, one file, one test file\n- No need for classes in the main module (just a function)\n\n### Don't Add\n- Command-line interfaces\n- Additional validation beyond what's specified\n- Custom exceptions (just return bool)\n- Logging\n- Configuration options\n- Additional helper functions (unless truly necessary for readability)\n\n### Decision Points\n- If unsure whether a character is \"allowed\", refer to the spec: `a-z, A-Z, 0-9, . _ % + -`\n- If unsure about edge cases not covered in tests, implement the safest interpretation that follows the rules\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ“‹ Summary\n\n**Create two files:**\n\n1. **`email_validator.py`** containing:\n   - `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` function\n   - Implements all 8 validation rules\n   - Uses only stdlib (no external deps)\n   - Clean, documented code\n\n2. **`test_email_validator.py`** containing:\n   - pytest tests for all specified valid emails\n   - pytest tests for all specified invalid emails\n   - Additional edge case coverage\n\n**Verify with:**\n```bash\nuv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\nuv run ruff check .\nuv run ruff format --check .\n```\n\n**Commit when complete.**\n","numLines":336,"startLine":1,"totalLines":336}}}

Length checks are O(1) after split\n3. Dot checks are simple string operations\n4. Character validation is the most expensive, done last\n\nUsing string methods instead of regex keeps the code readable and avoids import overhead. cheaper checks first:\n    67â†’1. `@` symbol check is O(n) but catches most invalid inputs immediately\n    68â†’2. Character validation is the most expensive, done last\n    71â†’\n    72â†’Using string methods instead of regex keeps the code readable and avoids import overhead. Implement validation rules in order:\n   - Check for exactly one `@` symbol\n   - Split into local and domain parts\n   - Check local part length (1-64 chars)\n   - Check domain part length (1-255 chars)\n   - Check domain contains at least one dot\n   - Check no consecutive dots (`..`) anywhere\n   - Check no leading dot in local part\n   - Check no trailing dot in local part\n   - Check no leading dot in domain part\n   - Check no trailing dot in domain part\n   - Check all characters are allowed:\n     - Local part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n     - Domain part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n\n## Acceptance Criteria\n- [ ] File `email_validator.py` exists in project root\n- [ ] Function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` is defined\n- [ ] Function has proper type hints\n- [ ] Function has docstring explaining its purpose\n- [ ] All 8 validation rules are implemented\n- [ ] Function returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n- [ ] No external dependencies used\n- [ ] No regex used (string methods only)\n- [ ] Code passes `ruff check email_validator.py`\n- [ ] Code passes `ruff format --check email_validator.py`\n\n## Code Review Checklist\n- [ ] Function signature matches spec exactly\n- [ ] Type hints are correct (str -> bool)\n- [ ] Docstring is present and accurate\n- [ ] Validation rules are in logical order\n- [ ] Early returns for efficiency\n- [ ] No dead code or unused variables\n- [ ] Follows Python naming conventions (snake_case)\n- [ ] No over-engineering (just one function)\n\n## Reasoning Trace\nThe validation order is designed for efficiency - cheaper checks first:\n1. `@` symbol check is O(n) but catches most invalid inputs immediately\n2. Length checks are O(1) after split\n3. Dot checks are simple string operations\n4. Character validation is the most expensive, done last\n\nUsing string methods instead of regex keeps the code readable and avoids import overhead. The function is intentionally simple - no custom exceptions, no logging, just a bool return.\n","numLines":73,"startLine":1,"totalLines":73}}}

Implement `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` function with docstring\n    4. Implement validation rules in this order (see PROMPT.md lines 4-17):\n       - Check exactly one `@` symbol using `email.count('@') == 1`\n       - Split using `email.split('@', 1)` to get local and domain parts\n       - Check local part length: `1 <= len(local) <= 64`\n       - Check domain part length: `1 <= len(domain) <= 255`\n       - Check domain contains at least one dot: `'.' in domain`\n       - Check no consecutive dots: `'..' not in email`\n       - Check no leading/trailing dots in local: `not local.startswith('.') and not local.endswith('.')`\n       - Check no leading/trailing dots in domain: `not domain.startswith('.') and not domain.endswith('.')`\n       - Check all local chars in LOCAL_ALLOWED: `all(c in LOCAL_ALLOWED for c in local)`\n       - Check all domain chars in DOMAIN_ALLOWED: `all(c in DOMAIN_ALLOWED for c in domain)`\n    5. Run linting: `uv run ruff check email_validator.py && uv run ruff format --check email_validator.py`\n\n  - **Context (read-only):**\n    - `.claudiomiro/AI_PROMPT.md:51-62` â€” Function signature pattern\n    - `.claudiomiro/TASK1/PROMPT.md:4-17` â€” Validation rules in order\n    - `.claudiomiro/TASK1/PROMPT.md:68-71` â€” Character set definitions\n\n  - **Touched (will modify/create):**\n    - CREATE: `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/email_validator.py`\n\n  - **Interfaces / Contracts:**\n    - Export: `validate_email(email: str) -> bool`\n    - Returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n    - No exceptions raised - pure boolean return\n\n  - **Tests:**\n    N/A for this item - tests are in a separate task (TASK2). However, manual verification:\n    - `from email_validator import validate_email; assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") == True`\n    - `from email_validator import validate_email; assert validate_email(\"invalid\") == False`\n\n  - **Migrations / Data:**\n    N/A - No data changes\n\n  - **Observability:**\n    N/A - No observability requirements\n\n  - **Security & Permissions:**\n    - Input validation: Function handles any string input safely, returns False for malformed input\n    - No PII handling concerns (just validation, no storage)\n\n  - **Performance:**\n    - Validation order optimized: cheap checks first (@ count, length) before expensive character iteration\n    - O(n) complexity where n = email length\n    - No performance concerns for typical email strings (<320 chars)\n\n  - **Commands:**\n    ```bash\n    # Lint check\n    uv run ruff check email_validator.py\n\n    # Format check\n    uv run ruff format --check email_validator.py\n\n    # Quick manual test\n    uv run python -c \"from email_validator import validate_email; print(validate_email('user@example.com')); print(validate_email('invalid'))\"\n    ```\n\n  - **Risks & Mitigations:**\n    - **Risk:** Character set might be incomplete or incorrect\n      **Mitigation:** Use exact sets from PROMPT.md lines 68-71\n    - **Risk:** Edge cases with empty strings or None input\n      **Mitigation:** Empty local/domain caught by length checks; function expects str type per signature\n\n## Diff Test Plan\n\n**Changed symbols:** `validate_email` function (new)\n\n**Test cases required:**\n| Scenario | Input | Expected | Notes |\n|----------|-------|----------|-------|\n| Happy path - simple email | `\"user@example.com\"` | `True` | Basic valid email |\n| Happy path - dots in local | `\"user.name@domain.co.uk\"` | `True` | Multiple parts |\n| Happy path - plus tag | `\"user+tag@example.org\"` | `True` | Plus sign allowed in local |\n| Error - no local part | `\"@example.com\"` | `False` | Missing local |\n| Error - no domain | `\"user@\"` | `False` | Missing domain |\n| Error - double @ | `\"user@@example.com\"` | `False` | Multiple @ |\n| Error - leading dot domain | `\"user@.com\"` | `False` | Dot at start of domain |\n| Error - consecutive dots | `\"user@example..com\"` | `False` | Double dots |\n\n**Coverage target:** 100% of validation branches\n\n## Verification (global)\n- [ ] Run lint for changed code only:\n      ```bash\n      uv run ruff check email_validator.py\n      uv run ruff format --check email_validator.py\n      ```\n      CRITICAL: Do not run full-project checks\n- [ ] Manual verification: import and test with valid/invalid emails\n- [ ] All 11 validation rules implemented (see PROMPT.md lines 4-17)\n- [ ] Function signature matches spec: `validate_email(email: str) -> bool`\n- [ ] Code follows conventions from AI_PROMPT.md (no regex, stdlib only)\n\n## Acceptance Criteria\n- [ ] File `email_validator.py` exists in project root\n- [ ] Function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` is defined with proper type hints\n- [ ] Function has docstring explaining its purpose\n- [ ] All 11 validation rules are implemented (see PROMPT.md lines 4-17)\n- [ ] Function returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n- [ ] No external dependencies used (stdlib only)\n- [ ] No regex used (string methods only)\n- [ ] `uv run ruff check email_validator.py` passes with no errors\n- [ ] `uv run ruff format --check email_validator.py` passes with no errors\n\n## Impact Analysis\n- **Directly impacted:**\n  - Use only Python stdlib - no external libraries and no regex.\n\n**Validation Rules to Implement (in order):**\n1. Exactly one `@` symbol required\n2. Split into local part (before @) and domain part (after @)\n3. Local part must be 1-64 characters\n4. Domain part must be 1-255 characters\n5. Domain must contain at least one dot (`.`)\n6. No consecutive dots (`..`) anywhere in the email\n7. No leading dot in local part (e.g., `.user@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n8. No trailing dot in local part (e.g., `user.@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n9. No leading dot in domain part (e.g., `user@.example.com` â†’ invalid)\n10. No trailing dot in domain part (e.g., `user@example.com.` â†’ invalid)\n11. Only allowed characters:\n    - Local part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n    - Domain part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n\n**Expected Function Signature:**\n```python\ndef validate_email(email: str) -> bool:\n    \"\"\"Validate email address according to specified rules.\n\n    Args:\n        email: The email address to validate.\n\n    Returns:\n        True if valid, False otherwise.\n    \"\"\"\n```\n\nAfter implementation, verify with:\n```bash\nuv run ruff check email_validator.py\nuv run ruff format --check email_validator.py\n```\n\n## COMPLEXITY\nLow\n\n## CONTEXT REFERENCE\n**For complete environment context, read:**\n- `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/.claudiomiro/AI_PROMPT.md` - Implement validation rules in this order (see PROMPT.md lines 4-17):\n       - Check exactly one `@` symbol using `email.count('@') == 1`\n       - Split using `email.split('@', 1)` to get local and domain parts\n       - Check local part length: `1 <= len(local) <= 64`\n       - Check domain part length: `1 <= len(domain) <= 255`\n       - Check domain contains at least one dot: `'.' in domain`\n       - Check no consecutive dots: `'..' not in email`\n       - Check no leading/trailing dots in local: `not local.startswith('.') and not local.endswith('.')`\n       - Check no leading/trailing dots in domain: `not domain.startswith('.') and not domain.endswith('.')`\n       - Check all local chars in LOCAL_ALLOWED: `all(c in LOCAL_ALLOWED for c in local)`\n       - Check all domain chars in DOMAIN_ALLOWED: `all(c in DOMAIN_ALLOWED for c in domain)`\n    5. no local part | `\"@example.com\"` | `False` | Missing local |\n| Error - no domain | `\"user@\"` | `False` | Missing domain |\n| Error - double @ | `\"user@@example.com\"` | `False` | Multiple @ |\n| Error - Running linting checks\n\n**Decision: DO NOT SPLIT**\n\n**Reasoning:**\n1. **Single file, single function** - This is a cohesive unit of work that creates one file with one function\n2. **Low complexity** - Marked as \"Low\" complexity in the task itself\n3. **No meaningful parallelism** - All validation rules must be in the same function; they cannot be implemented independently\n4. **Fast to implement** - This is straightforward Python string manipulation\n5. **Atomic deliverable** - The function either works or it doesn't; partial implementations have no value\n6. **Sequential dependencies within task** - The function must be complete before tests (TASK2) can run against it\n\nSplitting this into subtasks (e.g., \"create file\", \"implement rules 1-5\", \"implement rules 6-11\", \"run linting\") would:\n- Add overhead without reducing cycle time\n- Create artificial fragmentation\n- Not enable any parallelism (all work is in the same file/function)\n- Violate the \"independently executable and testable\" rule (a half-implemented function isn't testable)\n\nThe current structure is already optimal:\n- TASK1: Implement the validator (foundation, no dependencies)\n- TASK2: Write tests (depends on TASK1)  \n- TASKÎ©: Final verification (depends on TASK1, TASK2)\n\n---\n\n**Summary:** No changes made. Define function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` with docstring\n    3. Implement validation rules in this order (efficient early-exit pattern):\n       - Return False if `email.count('@') != 1`\n       - Split into `local, domain = email.split('@')`\n       - Return False if local part length not in range 1-64\n       - Return False if domain part length not in range 1-255\n       - Return False if `'.' not in domain`\n       - Return False if `'..' in email` (consecutive dots anywhere)\n       - Return False if `local.startswith('.')` or `local.endswith('.')`\n       - Return False if `domain.startswith('.')` or `domain.endswith('.')`\n       - Validate allowed characters:\n         - Local part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n         - Domain part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n       - Return True if all checks pass\n    4. Define function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` with docstring\n    27â†’    3. Implement validation rules in this order (efficient early-exit pattern):\n    28â†’       - Return False if `email.count('@') != 1`\n    29â†’       - Split into `local, domain = email.split('@')`\n    30â†’       - Return False if local part length not in range 1-64\n    31â†’       - Return False if domain part length not in range 1-255\n    32â†’       - Return False if `'.' not in domain`\n    33â†’       - Return False if `'..' in email` (consecutive dots anywhere)\n    34â†’       - Return False if `local.startswith('.')` or `local.endswith('.')`\n    35â†’       - Return False if `domain.startswith('.')` or `domain.endswith('.')`\n    36â†’       - Validate allowed characters:\n    37â†’         - Local part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n    38â†’         - Domain part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n    39â†’       - Return True if all checks pass\n    40â†’    4. Implement validation rules in this order (efficient early-exit pattern):\n       - Return False if `email.count('@') != 1`\n       - Split into `local, domain = email.split('@')`\n       - Return False if local part length not in range 1-64\n       - Return False if domain part length not in range 1-255\n       - Return False if `'.' not in domain`\n       - Return False if `'..' in email` (consecutive dots anywhere)\n       - Return False if `local.startswith('.')` or `local.endswith('.')`\n       - Return False if `domain.startswith('.')` or `domain.endswith('.')`\n       - Validate allowed characters:\n         - Local part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n         - Domain part: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n       - Return True if all checks pass\n    4.
