Fix any issues\n\n### Implementation Approach\n\n**Recommended validation order (in function):**\n1. Check for exactly one `@` symbol (reject if not)\n2. Split into local and domain parts\n3. Check local part length (1-64)\n4. Check domain part length (1-255)\n5. Check domain has at least one dot\n6. Check no consecutive dots anywhere\n7. Check no leading/trailing dots in local part\n8. Check no leading/trailing dots in domain part\n9. Check all characters are in allowed set\n\n**Character validation:**\n- Allowed in both local and domain: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n- Allowed ONLY in local part: `_`, `%`, `+`\n- The `@` symbol is the separator (already validated)\n\n### Expected Artifacts\n\n| File | Purpose |\n|------|---------|\n| `email_validator.py` | Main module with `validate_email` function |\n| `test_email_validator.py` | Comprehensive pytest test suite |\n\n### Constraints\n- **DO NOT** use external email validation libraries\n- **DO NOT** use `re` module for regex (use string methods for simplicity and clarity)\n- **DO NOT** create additional helper files\n- **DO NOT** over-engineer - keep it simple and readable\n- **DO NOT** add features beyond what's specified\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§ª Testing Guidance\n\n### Test Structure\n```python\n# test_email_validator.py\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n### Required Test Categories\n\n**1. Valid emails (happy path):**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**2. Invalid - structural issues:**\n- `@example.com` - missing local part\n- `user@` - missing domain\n- `user@@example.com` - multiple @ symbols\n- `userexample.com` - no @ symbol\n- Empty string\n\n**3. Invalid - dot issues:**\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `.user@example.com` - leading dot in local\n- `user.@example.com` - trailing dot in local\n- `user@example.com.` - trailing dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots in domain\n- `user..name@example.com` - consecutive dots in local\n\n**4. Invalid - length issues:**\n- Local part > 64 chars\n- Domain part > 255 chars\n- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n\n**5. Invalid - character issues:**\n- `user name@example.com` - space\n- `user@exam ple.com` - space in domain\n- `user!@example.com` - disallowed character\n- `user@example#.com` - disallowed character in domain\n\n**6. Invalid - domain structure:**\n- `user@example` - no dot in domain\n\n### Minimum Test Count\n- At least 3 valid email tests (as specified)\n- At least 5 invalid email tests (as specified)\n- Additional edge case tests recommended\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ” Verification and Traceability\n\n### Pre-Completion Checklist\n\nBefore marking complete, verify:\n\n1. **Files exist:**\n   - Rule 1: Exactly one @ symbol\n    if email.count(\"@\") != 1:\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 2: Split into local and domain parts\n    local, domain = email.split(\"@\", 1)\n\n    # Rule 3: Local part must be 1-64 characters\n    if not (1 <= len(local) <= 64):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 4: Domain part must be 1-255 characters\n    if not (1 <= len(domain) <= 255):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 5: Domain must contain at least one dot\n    if \".\" not in domain:\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 6: No consecutive dots anywhere\n    if \"..\" in email:\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 7: No leading dot in local part\n    if local.startswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 8: No trailing dot in local part\n    if local.endswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 9: No leading dot in domain part\n    if domain.startswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 10: No trailing dot in domain part\n    if domain.endswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 11: Only allowed characters\n    if not all(c in LOCAL_ALLOWED for c in local):\n        return False\n\n    if not all(c in DOMAIN_ALLOWED for c in domain):\n        return False\n\n    return True\n","numLines":67,"startLine":1,"totalLines":67}}}

Implement `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` function with docstring\n    31â†’    4. Implement validation rules in this order (see PROMPT.md lines 4-17):\n    32â†’       - Check exactly one `@` symbol using `email.count('@') == 1`\n    33â†’       - Split using `email.split('@', 1)` to get local and domain parts\n    34â†’       - Check local part length: `1 <= len(local) <= 64`\n    35â†’       - Check domain part length: `1 <= len(domain) <= 255`\n    36â†’       - Check domain contains at least one dot: `'.' in domain`\n    37â†’       - Check no consecutive dots: `'..' not in email`\n    38â†’       - Check no leading/trailing dots in local: `not local.startswith('.') and not local.endswith('.')`\n    39â†’       - Check no leading/trailing dots in domain: `not domain.startswith('.') and not domain.endswith('.')`\n    40â†’       - Check all local chars in LOCAL_ALLOWED: `all(c in LOCAL_ALLOWED for c in local)`\n    41â†’       - Check all domain chars in DOMAIN_ALLOWED: `all(c in DOMAIN_ALLOWED for c in domain)`\n    42â†’    5. Implement `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` function with docstring\n    4. Implement validation rules in this order (see PROMPT.md lines 4-17):\n       - Check exactly one `@` symbol using `email.count('@') == 1`\n       - Split using `email.split('@', 1)` to get local and domain parts\n       - Check local part length: `1 <= len(local) <= 64`\n       - Check domain part length: `1 <= len(domain) <= 255`\n       - Check domain contains at least one dot: `'.' in domain`\n       - Check no consecutive dots: `'..' not in email`\n       - Check no leading/trailing dots in local: `not local.startswith('.') and not local.endswith('.')`\n       - Check no leading/trailing dots in domain: `not domain.startswith('.') and not domain.endswith('.')`\n       - Check all local chars in LOCAL_ALLOWED: `all(c in LOCAL_ALLOWED for c in local)`\n       - Check all domain chars in DOMAIN_ALLOWED: `all(c in DOMAIN_ALLOWED for c in domain)`\n    5. Run linting: `uv run ruff check email_validator.py && uv run ruff format --check email_validator.py`\n\n  - **Context (read-only):**\n    - `.claudiomiro/AI_PROMPT.md:51-62` â€” Function signature pattern\n    - `.claudiomiro/TASK1/PROMPT.md:4-17` â€” Validation rules in order\n    - `.claudiomiro/TASK1/PROMPT.md:68-71` â€” Character set definitions\n\n  - **Touched (will modify/create):**\n    - CREATE: `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/email_validator.py`\n\n  - **Interfaces / Contracts:**\n    - Export: `validate_email(email: str) -> bool`\n    - Returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n    - No exceptions raised - pure boolean return\n\n  - **Tests:**\n    N/A for this item - tests are in a separate task (TASK2). Find and learn from what already exists.\n     8â†’\n     9â†’---\n    10â†’\n    11â†’## ðŸ” What RESEARCH.md Should Contain\n    12â†’\n    13â†’RESEARCH.md is the agent's **learning phase** before execution. It should answer:\n    14â†’\n    15â†’1. **What patterns already exist** that I can follow?\n    16â†’2. **What components can I reuse** instead of creating new ones?\n    17â†’3. **How have similar problems been solved** in this codebase?\n    18â†’4. **What are the integration points** and dependencies?\n    19â†’5. **What tests patterns exist** that I should follow?\n    20â†’\n    21â†’---\n    22â†’\n    23â†’## ðŸ“š Research Methodology\n    24â†’\n    25â†’### Phase 1: Find Similar Implementations\n    26â†’\n    27â†’**Goal:** Locate code that solves similar problems to learn from.\n    28â†’\n    29â†’#### 1.1 Search Strategy\n    30â†’\n    31â†’```markdown\n    32â†’## Finding Similar Components\n    33â†’\n    34â†’**Search patterns to use:**\n    35â†’\n    36â†’1. **By functionality:**\n    37â†’   - Search for keywords from the task (e.g., \"validation\", \"parser\", \"handler\")\n    38â†’   - Look for similar feature names or concepts\n    39â†’   - Find related domain logic\n    40â†’\n    41â†’2. **By file patterns:**\n    42â†’   - If creating `user-service.ext`, search for `*-service.ext`\n    43â†’   - If creating `data-validator.ext`, search for `*-validator.ext`\n    44â†’   - Match naming conventions from the codebase\n    45â†’\n    46â†’3. **By architectural layer:**\n    47â†’   - Controllers: `src/controllers/**/*.ext`\n    48â†’   - Services: `src/services/**/*.ext`\n    49â†’   - Models: `src/models/**/*.ext`\n    50â†’   - Utils: `src/utils/**/*.ext`\n    51â†’   - Middleware: `src/middleware/**/*.ext`\n    52â†’\n    53â†’4. **By test patterns:**\n    54â†’   - Find test files for similar components\n    55â†’   - Look for test helpers and mocks\n    56â†’   - Understand testing approach (unit vs integration)\n    57â†’```\n    58â†’\n    59â†’#### 1.2 Analysis Depth\n    60â†’\n    61â†’For each similar component found, document:\n    62â†’\n    63â†’```markdown\n    64â†’## Similar Components Found\n    65â†’\n    66â†’### Component: `path/to/similar-component.ext`\n    67â†’- **Similarity:** [How it relates to your task]\n    68â†’- **Patterns to reuse:**\n    69â†’  - Line X-Y: [Pattern description]\n    70â†’  - Line A-B: [Another pattern]\n    71â†’- **Key learnings:**\n    72â†’  - Error handling approach at line Z\n    73â†’  - Validation pattern at line W\n    74â†’  - Dependencies used (imports)\n    75â†’  - Testing approach from `test-file.ext:lines`\n    76â†’\n    77â†’**Reuse decision:**\n    78â†’- [ ] Use as-is (import/extend)\n    79â†’- [ ] Adapt pattern\n    80â†’- [ ] Learn structure only\n    81â†’```\n    82â†’\n    83â†’---\n    84â†’\n    85â†’### Phase 2: Identify Reusable Components\n    86â†’\n    87â†’**Goal:** Find existing utilities, helpers, and libraries to leverage.\n    88â†’\n    89â†’#### 2.1 Common Reusable Patterns\n    90â†’\n    91â†’```markdown\n    92â†’## Reusable Components Checklist\n    93â†’\n    94â†’**Before creating new code, check if these exist:**\n    95â†’\n    96â†’- [ ] **Validation utilities:**\n    97â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"validate\" src/utils`\n    98â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"schema\" src/`\n    99â†’  - Common locations: `src/utils/validation.ext`, `src/validators/`\n   100â†’\n   101â†’- [ ] **Error handling:**\n   102â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"Error\" src/utils`\n   103â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"throw\" src/services`\n   104â†’  - Common locations: `src/utils/errors.ext`, `src/exceptions/`\n   105â†’\n   106â†’- [ ] **Data processing:**\n   107â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"transform\" src/utils`\n   108â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"format\" src/utils`\n   109â†’  - Common locations: `src/utils/formatters.ext`, `src/transformers/`\n   110â†’\n   111â†’- [ ] **Database/API helpers:**\n   112â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"query\" src/`\n   113â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"request\" src/`\n   114â†’  - Common locations: `src/db/`, `src/api/`, `src/services/`\n   115â†’\n   116â†’- [ ] **Authentication/Authorization:**\n   117â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"auth\" src/`\n   118â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"permission\" src/`\n   119â†’  - Common locations: `src/middleware/auth.ext`, `src/auth/`\n   120â†’\n   121â†’- [ ] **Configuration:**\n   122â†’  - Search: `config`, `.env`, `settings`\n   123â†’  - Common locations: `src/config/`, `.env.example`\n   124â†’\n   125â†’- [ ] **Logging:**\n   126â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"log\" src/`\n   127â†’  - Common locations: `src/utils/logger.ext`, `logger.js`\n   128â†’\n   129â†’- [ ] **Test utilities:**\n   130â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"mock\" __tests__`\n   131â†’  - Search: `grep -r \"helper\" __tests__`\n   132â†’  - Common locations: `__tests__/helpers/`, `__tests__/__mocks__/`\n   133â†’```\n   134â†’\n   135â†’#### 2.2 Document Reusable Components\n   136â†’\n   137â†’```markdown\n   138â†’## Reusable Components Found\n   139â†’\n   140â†’### 1. [Component Name] - `path/to/component.ext`\n   141â†’**Purpose:** [What it does]\n   142â†’**How to use:**\n   143â†’- Import: `import { X } from 'path/to/component'`\n   144â†’- Usage example from `reference-file.ext:lines`\n   145â†’- Parameters: [signature]\n   146â†’**Integration:** [How to integrate into your task]\n   147â†’\n   148â†’### 2. [Another Component] - `path/to/other.ext`\n   149â†’...\n   150â†’```\n   151â†’\n   152â†’---\n   153â†’\n   154â†’### Phase 3: Understand Codebase Conventions\n   155â†’\n   156â†’**Goal:** Learn the project's style, patterns, and conventions.\n   157â†’\n   158â†’#### 3.1 Convention Discovery\n   159â†’\n   160â†’```markdown\n   161â†’## Codebase Conventions Discovered\n   162â†’\n   163â†’### File Organization\n   164â†’- **Pattern found in:** `src/services/example-service.ext`\n   165â†’- **Structure:**\n   166â†’  ```\n   167â†’  - imports (dependencies)\n   168â†’  - constants/types\n   169â†’  - helper functions\n   170â†’  - main exported functions\n   171â†’  - module.exports or export default\n   172â†’  ```\n   173â†’\n   174â†’### Naming Conventions\n   175â†’- **Files:** `kebab-case.ext` (e.g., `user-service.js`)\n   176â†’- **Classes:** `PascalCase` (e.g., `UserService`)\n   177â†’- **Functions:** `camelCase` (e.g., `getUserById`)\n   178â†’- **Constants:** `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE` (e.g., `MAX_RETRIES`)\n   179â†’- **Discovered from:** `path/to/reference-file.ext`\n   180â†’\n   181â†’### Error Handling Pattern\n   182â†’- **Pattern:** Try-catch with custom errors\n   183â†’- **Example from:** `path/to/service.ext:45-60`\n   184â†’  ```\n   185â†’  try {\n   186â†’    // operation\n   187â†’  } catch (error) {\n   188â†’    logger.error('Context', error);\n   189â†’    throw new CustomError('Message', { cause: error });\n   190â†’  }\n   191â†’  ```\n   192â†’\n   193â†’### Testing Patterns\n   194â†’- **Test file location:** `__tests__/` or `*.test.ext` next to source\n   195â†’- **Test structure:** Describe-it with arrange-act-assert\n   196â†’- **Mocking approach:** [Jest mocks / manual mocks / etc.]\n   197â†’- **Example from:** `path/to/example.test.ext:20-50`\n   198â†’\n   199â†’### Import/Export Style\n   200â†’- **CommonJS:** `const X = require('...')` and `module.exports = { X }`\n   201â†’- **ES Modules:** `import X from '...'` and `export { X }`\n   202â†’- **Detected from:** [analysis of existing files]\n   203â†’\n   204â†’### Documentation Style\n   205â†’- **Comments:** [JSDoc / docstrings / inline comments]\n   206â†’- **Example from:** `path/to/documented-file.ext:10-15`\n   207â†’```\n   208â†’\n   209â†’---\n   210â†’\n   211â†’### Phase 4: Map Integration Points\n   212â†’\n   213â†’**Goal:** Understand how your changes fit into the larger system.\n   214â†’\n   215â†’#### 4.1 Integration Analysis\n   216â†’\n   217â†’```markdown\n   218â†’## Integration & Impact Analysis\n   219â†’\n   220â†’### Upstream Dependencies (What I need from previous work)\n   221â†’1. **[Component/Module Name]** from `path/to/file.ext`\n   222â†’   - **What I need:** [Data structure / function / API]\n   223â†’   - **Contract:** [Interface definition]\n   224â†’   - **Location:** `file.ext:lines`\n   225â†’   - **How to access:** [Import path / API endpoint]\n   226â†’\n   227â†’2. **[Another Dependency]**\n   228â†’   ...\n   229â†’\n   230â†’### Downstream Consumers (What depends on my changes)\n   231â†’1. **[Component/Module]** at `path/to/consumer.ext:lines`\n   232â†’   - **What it expects:** [Interface / contract]\n   233â†’   - **Breaking changes risk:** YES/NO\n   234â†’   - **Migration needed:** YES/NO\n   235â†’   - **Verification:** [How to verify integration]\n   236â†’\n   237â†’2. **[Another Consumer]**\n   238â†’   ...\n   239â†’\n   240â†’### Shared Interfaces / Contracts\n   241â†’```markdown\n   242â†’**Interface 1: [Name]**\n   243â†’- **Type/Schema:** [Definition]\n   244â†’- **Used by:** [List of files]\n   245â†’- **Defined in:** `path/to/types.ext:lines`\n   246â†’- **Must maintain:** [Compatibility requirements]\n   247â†’\n   248â†’**Interface 2: [Name]**\n   249â†’...\n   250â†’```\n   251â†’\n   252â†’### Database Schema Dependencies\n   253â†’- **Tables affected:** [table names]\n   254â†’- **Columns needed:** [column list]\n   255â†’- **Constraints:** [foreign keys, indexes]\n   256â†’- **Migration strategy:** [How to handle schema changes]\n   257â†’\n   258â†’### API Endpoints Involved\n   259â†’- **Existing endpoints to modify:**\n   260â†’  - `METHOD /path` in `file.ext:lines`\n   261â†’- **New endpoints to create:**\n   262â†’  - `METHOD /new-path` - [purpose]\n   263â†’- **Compatibility:** [Breaking changes? Versioning needed?]\n   264â†’\n   265â†’### Configuration Dependencies\n   266â†’- **Environment variables:** [List with purposes]\n   267â†’- **Config files:** `path/to/config.ext`\n   268â†’- **Defaults:** [Where to set defaults]\n   269â†’```\n   270â†’\n   271â†’---\n   272â†’\n   273â†’### Phase 5: Test Strategy Discovery\n   274â†’\n   275â†’**Goal:** Understand how to test following project conventions.\n   276â†’\n   277â†’#### 5.1 Test Pattern Analysis\n   278â†’\n   279â†’```markdown\n   280â†’## Test Strategy from Codebase\n   281â†’\n   282â†’### Testing Framework Detected\n   283â†’- **Framework:** [Jest / pytest / go test / JUnit / RSpec / etc.]\n   284â†’- **Test runner command:** `[actual command from package.json or scripts]`\n   285â†’- **Config location:** `[jest.config.js / pytest.ini / etc.]`\n   286â†’\n   287â†’### Test File Patterns Found\n   288â†’- **Unit tests:** `__tests__/*.test.ext` or `*.test.ext`\n   289â†’- **Integration tests:** `__tests__/integration/*.test.ext`\n   290â†’- **E2E tests:** `__tests__/e2e/*.test.ext` (if exists)\n   291â†’\n   292â†’### Test Structure Pattern\n   293â†’**Found in:** `path/to/example.test.ext`\n   294â†’\n   295â†’```[language]\n   296â†’describe('[Component]', () => {\n   297â†’  // Setup (beforeEach, fixtures)\n   298â†’\n   299â†’  describe('[function/method]', () => {\n   300â†’    it('should [expected behavior]', () => {\n   301â†’      // Arrange\n   302â†’      const input = ...\n   303â†’\n   304â†’      // Act\n   305â†’      const result = functionUnderTest(input)\n   306â†’\n   307â†’      // Assert\n   308â†’      expect(result).toBe(...)\n   309â†’    })\n   310â†’  })\n   311â†’})\n   312â†’```\n   313â†’\n   314â†’### Mocking Patterns\n   315â†’- **Mock location:** `__tests__/__mocks__/`\n   316â†’- **Mock pattern from:** `path/to/mock-example.ext:lines`\n   317â†’- **How to mock:**\n   318â†’  - External APIs: [pattern]\n   319â†’  - Database: [pattern]\n   320â†’  - File system: [pattern]\n   321â†’  - Time/Date: [pattern]\n   322â†’\n   323â†’### Test Data / Fixtures\n   324â†’- **Location:** `__tests__/fixtures/` or `__tests__/mocks/`\n   325â†’- **Pattern:** [How test data is organized]\n   326â†’- **Example from:** `path/to/fixture.ext`\n   327â†’\n   328â†’### Coverage Expectations\n   329â†’- **Current project coverage:** [percentage from config or CI]\n   330â†’- **Coverage command:** `[actual command]`\n   331â†’- **Minimum required:** [threshold from config]\n   332â†’```\n   333â†’\n   334â†’---\n   335â†’\n   336â†’### Phase 6: Risk and Challenge Assessment\n   337â†’\n   338â†’**Goal:** Identify potential issues before implementation.\n   339â†’\n   340â†’```markdown\n   341â†’## Risks & Challenges Identified\n   342â†’\n   343â†’### Technical Risks\n   344â†’\n   345â†’1. **[Risk Name]**\n   346â†’   - **Description:** [What could go wrong]\n   347â†’   - **Likelihood:** Low / Medium / High\n   348â†’   - **Impact:** Low / Medium / High\n   349â†’   - **Evidence:** [Why you think this is a risk]\n   350â†’   - **Mitigation:** [How to prevent or handle it]\n   351â†’   - **Fallback:** [Plan B if mitigation fails]\n   352â†’\n   353â†’2. **[Another Risk]**\n   354â†’   ...\n   355â†’\n   356â†’### Complexity Assessment\n   357â†’- **Overall complexity:** Low / Medium / High\n   358â†’- **Reasoning:** [Why this complexity level]\n   359â†’- **Complex areas:**\n   360â†’  1. [Area]: [Why complex]\n   361â†’  2. [Area]: [Why complex]\n   362â†’\n   363â†’### Missing Information / Ambiguities\n   364â†’- [ ] **[What's unclear]**\n   365â†’  - **Context:** [Why this is needed]\n   366â†’  - **Impact:** [What happens if we don't clarify]\n   367â†’  - **Recommendation:** [Suggested approach]\n   368â†’\n   369â†’### External Dependencies\n   370â†’- **Third-party packages needed:** [list]\n   371â†’- **API dependencies:** [external services]\n   372â†’- **Version constraints:** [compatibility requirements]\n   373â†’```\n   374â†’\n   375â†’---\n   376â†’\n   377â†’## ðŸŽ¯ RESEARCH.md Template Output\n   378â†’\n   379â†’After completing all research phases, generate this structured file:\n   380â†’\n   381â†’```markdown\n   382â†’# Research for [TASK-NAME]\n   383â†’\n   384â†’## Context Reference\n   385â†’**For tech stack and conventions, see:**\n   386â†’- `path/to/AI_PROMPT.md` - Universal context\n   387â†’- `path/to/TASK.md` - Task-level context\n   388â†’- `path/to/PROMPT.md` - Task-specific context\n   389â†’\n   390â†’**This file contains ONLY new information discovered during research.**\n   391â†’\n   392â†’---\n   393â†’\n   394â†’## Task Understanding Summary\n   395â†’[1-2 sentence summary - reference TODO.md for full details]\n   396â†’\n   397â†’---\n   398â†’\n   399â†’## Similar Components Found (LEARN FROM THESE)\n   400â†’\n   401â†’### 1. [Component Name] - `path/to/similar.ext:lines`\n   402â†’**Why similar:** [Explanation]\n   403â†’**Patterns to reuse:**\n   404â†’- Lines X-Y: [Pattern description]\n   405â†’- Lines A-B: [Another pattern]\n   406â†’**Key learnings:**\n   407â†’- [Learning 1]\n   408â†’- [Learning 2]\n   409â†’\n   410â†’### 2. [Another Component] - `path/to/other.ext:lines`\n   411â†’...\n   412â†’\n   413â†’---\n   414â†’\n   415â†’## Reusable Components (USE THESE, DON'T RECREATE)\n   416â†’\n   417â†’### 1. [Utility Name] - `path/to/utility.ext`\n   418â†’**Purpose:** [What it does]\n   419â†’**How to use:**\n   420â†’```[language]\n   421â†’import { X } from 'path/to/utility';\n   422â†’// Usage example\n   423â†’X.method(params);\n   424â†’```\n   425â†’**Integration into task:** [How you'll use it]\n   426â†’\n   427â†’### 2. [Another Utility] - `path/to/other-utility.ext`\n   428â†’...\n   429â†’\n   430â†’---\n   431â†’\n   432â†’## Codebase Conventions Discovered\n   433â†’\n   434â†’### File Organization\n   435â†’- Pattern: [Structure found in reference files]\n   436â†’- Example: `path/to/example.ext`\n   437â†’\n   438â†’### Naming Conventions\n   439â†’- Files: [convention]\n   440â†’- Functions: [convention]\n   441â†’- Classes: [convention]\n   442â†’- Constants: [convention]\n   443â†’\n   444â†’### Error Handling Pattern\n   445â†’```[language]\n   446â†’// Pattern from path/to/reference.ext:lines\n   447â†’[code example]\n   448â†’```\n   449â†’\n   450â†’### Testing Pattern\n   451â†’```[language]\n   452â†’// Pattern from path/to/test-example.test.ext:lines\n   453â†’[code example]\n   454â†’```\n   455â†’\n   456â†’---\n   457â†’\n   458â†’## Integration & Impact Analysis\n   459â†’\n   460â†’### Functions/Classes/Components Being Modified:\n   461â†’1. **`functionName`** in `path/to/file.ext:lines`\n   462â†’   - **Called by:**\n   463â†’     - `path/to/caller1.ext:line`\n   464â†’     - `path/to/caller2.ext:line`\n   465â†’   - **Parameter contract:** `function(param1: type1, param2: type2): returnType`\n   466â†’   - **Impact:** [How changes affect callers]\n   467â†’   - **Breaking changes:** YES/NO - [Explanation]\n   468â†’\n   469â†’### API/Database/External Integration:\n   470â†’[Only if applicable]\n   471â†’- **API endpoints affected:**\n   472â†’  - `METHOD /path` in `file.ext:lines` - [impact]\n   473â†’- **Database schema changes:**\n   474â†’  - Table: [changes needed]\n   475â†’- **External dependencies:**\n   476â†’  - [service/library] - [how used]\n   477â†’\n   478â†’---\n   479â†’\n   480â†’## Test Strategy Discovered\n   481â†’\n   482â†’### Testing Framework\n   483â†’- **Framework:** [Name]\n   484â†’- **Test command:** `[actual command]`\n   485â†’- **Config:** `path/to/config`\n   486â†’\n `path/to/mock-example.ext:lines`\n   496â†’\n   497â†’---\n   498â†’\n   499â†’## Risks & Challenges Identified\n   500â†’\n   501â†’### Technical Risks\n   502â†’1. **[Risk]**\n   503â†’   - Impact: [High/Medium/Low]\n   504â†’   - Mitigation: [Strategy]\n   505â†’\n   506â†’### Complexity Assessment\n   507â†’- Overall: [Low/Medium/High]\n   508â†’- Reasoning: [Why]\n   509â†’\n   510â†’### findings, execute in this order:**\n   518â†’\n   519â†’1. **[Step 1]** - [Specific action]\n   520â†’   - Read: `path/to/pattern.ext:lines`\n   521â†’   - Create/Modify: `path/to/target.ext`\n   522â†’   - Follow pattern from: [reference]\n   523â†’   - Test with: `[command]`\n   524â†’\n   525â†’2. **[Step 2]** - [Next action]\n   526â†’   - Reuse component: `path/to/utility.ext`\n   527â†’   - Integration point: `path/to/integration.ext:lines`\n   528â†’   - Verify: [how to verify]\n   529â†’\n   530â†’3. **[Step 3]** - [Final action]\n   531â†’   - Follow test pattern: `path/to/test-example.test.ext:lines`\n   532â†’   - Run: `[test command] path/to/new-test`\n   533â†’   - Acceptance: [criteria]\n   534â†’\n   535â†’---\n   536â†’\n   537â†’**Research completed:** code\n   634â†’4. âœ… **Test** using project conventions\n   635â†’5. âœ… **Execute** efficiently with a clear strategy\n   636â†’\n   637â†’**Impact Metrics:**\n   638â†’- **Code consistency:** 90%+ pattern adherence\n   639â†’- **Reuse rate:** 70%+ of utilities reused vs created\n   640â†’- **Integration success:** Zero breaking changes without migration\n   641â†’- **Test coverage:** Matches or The better the research, the better the implementation.\n   646â†’\n\n<system-reminder>\nWhenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.\n</system-reminder>\n"}]},"parent_tool_use_id":null,"session_id":"a7d0d344-9efc-4535-9a15-f49b767c809b","uuid":"950197e1-db20-4c74-8317-3e50986b5e24","tool_use_result":{"type":"text","file":{"filePath":"/Users/administrator/projects/claudiomiro/src/steps/step5/research.md","content":"# RESEARCH.md Generation Guide â€” Learn from the Codebase\n\n## ðŸŽ¯ Purpose\n\nThis document defines how step5 should generate RESEARCH.md files that help the agent leverage existing codebase patterns and components for consistency.\n\n**CRITICAL PRINCIPLE:** Don't reinvent the wheel. Find and learn from what already exists.\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ” What RESEARCH.md Should Contain\n\nRESEARCH.md is the agent's **learning phase** before execution. It should answer:\n\n1. **What patterns already exist** that I can follow?\n2. **What components can I reuse** instead of creating new ones?\n3. **How have similar problems been solved** in this codebase?\n4. **What are the integration points** and dependencies?\n5. **What tests patterns exist** that I should follow?\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ“š Research Methodology\n\n### Phase 1: Find Similar Implementations\n\n**Goal:** Locate code that solves similar problems to learn from.\n\n#### 1.1 Search Strategy\n\n```markdown\n## Finding Similar Components\n\n**Search patterns to use:**\n\n1. **By functionality:**\n   - Search for keywords from the task (e.g., \"validation\", \"parser\", \"handler\")\n   - Look for similar feature names or concepts\n   - Find related domain logic\n\n2. **By file patterns:**\n   - If creating `user-service.ext`, search for `*-service.ext`\n   - If creating `data-validator.ext`, search for `*-validator.ext`\n   - Match naming conventions from the codebase\n\n3. **By architectural layer:**\n   - Controllers: `src/controllers/**/*.ext`\n   - Services: `src/services/**/*.ext`\n   - Models: `src/models/**/*.ext`\n   - Utils: `src/utils/**/*.ext`\n   - Middleware: `src/middleware/**/*.ext`\n\n4. **By test patterns:**\n   - Find test files for similar components\n   - Look for test helpers and mocks\n   - Understand testing approach (unit vs integration)\n```\n\n#### 1.2 Analysis Depth\n\nFor each similar component found, document:\n\n```markdown\n## Similar Components Found\n\n### Component: `path/to/similar-component.ext`\n- **Similarity:** [How it relates to your task]\n- **Patterns to reuse:**\n  - Line X-Y: [Pattern description]\n  - Line A-B: [Another pattern]\n- **Key learnings:**\n  - Error handling approach at line Z\n  - Validation pattern at line W\n  - Dependencies used (imports)\n  - Testing approach from `test-file.ext:lines`\n\n**Reuse decision:**\n- [ ] Use as-is (import/extend)\n- [ ] Adapt pattern\n- [ ] Learn structure only\n```\n\n---\n\n### Phase 2: Identify Reusable Components\n\n**Goal:** Find existing utilities, helpers, and libraries to leverage.\n\n#### 2.1 Common Reusable Patterns\n\n```markdown\n## Reusable Components Checklist\n\n**Before creating new code, check if these exist:**\n\n- [ ] **Validation utilities:**\n  - Search: `grep -r \"validate\" src/utils`\n  - Search: `grep -r \"schema\" src/`\n  - Common locations: `src/utils/validation.ext`, `src/validators/`\n\n- [ ] **Error handling:**\n  - Search: `grep -r \"Error\" src/utils`\n  - Search: `grep -r \"throw\" src/services`\n  - Common locations: `src/utils/errors.ext`, `src/exceptions/`\n\n- [ ] **Data processing:**\n  - Search: `grep -r \"transform\" src/utils`\n  - Search: `grep -r \"format\" src/utils`\n  - Common locations: `src/utils/formatters.ext`, `src/transformers/`\n\n- [ ] **Database/API helpers:**\n  - Search: `grep -r \"query\" src/`\n  - Search: `grep -r \"request\" src/`\n  - Common locations: `src/db/`, `src/api/`, `src/services/`\n\n- [ ] **Authentication/Authorization:**\n  - Search: `grep -r \"auth\" src/`\n  - Search: `grep -r \"permission\" src/`\n  - Common locations: `src/middleware/auth.ext`, `src/auth/`\n\n- [ ] **Configuration:**\n  - Search: `config`, `.env`, `settings`\n  - Common locations: `src/config/`, `.env.example`\n\n- [ ] **Logging:**\n  - Search: `grep -r \"log\" src/`\n  - Common locations: `src/utils/logger.ext`, `logger.js`\n\n- [ ] **Test utilities:**\n  - Search: `grep -r \"mock\" __tests__`\n  - Search: `grep -r \"helper\" __tests__`\n  - Common locations: `__tests__/helpers/`, `__tests__/__mocks__/`\n```\n\n#### 2.2 Document Reusable Components\n\n```markdown\n## Reusable Components Found\n\n### 1. [Component Name] - `path/to/component.ext`\n**Purpose:** [What it does]\n**How to use:**\n- Import: `import { X } from 'path/to/component'`\n- Usage example from `reference-file.ext:lines`\n- Parameters: [signature]\n**Integration:** [How to integrate into your task]\n\n### 2. [Another Component] - `path/to/other.ext`\n...\n```\n\n---\n\n### Phase 3: Understand Codebase Conventions\n\n**Goal:** Learn the project's style, patterns, and conventions.\n\n#### 3.1 Convention Discovery\n\n```markdown\n## Codebase Conventions Discovered\n\n### File Organization\n- **Pattern found in:** `src/services/example-service.ext`\n- **Structure:**\n  ```\n  - imports (dependencies)\n  - constants/types\n  - helper functions\n  - main exported functions\n  - module.exports or export default\n  ```\n\n### Naming Conventions\n- **Files:** `kebab-case.ext` (e.g., `user-service.js`)\n- **Classes:** `PascalCase` (e.g., `UserService`)\n- **Functions:** `camelCase` (e.g., `getUserById`)\n- **Constants:** `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE` (e.g., `MAX_RETRIES`)\n- **Discovered from:** `path/to/reference-file.ext`\n\n### Error Handling Pattern\n- **Pattern:** Try-catch with custom errors\n- **Example from:** `path/to/service.ext:45-60`\n  ```\n  try {\n    // operation\n  } catch (error) {\n    logger.error('Context', error);\n    throw new CustomError('Message', { cause: error });\n  }\n  ```\n\n### Testing Patterns\n- **Test file location:** `__tests__/` or `*.test.ext` next to source\n- **Test structure:** Describe-it with arrange-act-assert\n- **Mocking approach:** [Jest mocks / manual mocks / etc.]\n- **Example from:** `path/to/example.test.ext:20-50`\n\n### Import/Export Style\n- **CommonJS:** `const X = require('...')` and `module.exports = { X }`\n- **ES Modules:** `import X from '...'` and `export { X }`\n- **Detected from:** [analysis of existing files]\n\n### Documentation Style\n- **Comments:** [JSDoc / docstrings / inline comments]\n- **Example from:** `path/to/documented-file.ext:10-15`\n```\n\n---\n\n### Phase 4: Map Integration Points\n\n**Goal:** Understand how your changes fit into the larger system.\n\n#### 4.1 Integration Analysis\n\n```markdown\n## Integration & Impact Analysis\n\n### Upstream Dependencies (What I need from previous work)\n1. **[Component/Module Name]** from `path/to/file.ext`\n   - **What I need:** [Data structure / function / API]\n   - **Contract:** [Interface definition]\n   - **Location:** `file.ext:lines`\n   - **How to access:** [Import path / API endpoint]\n\n2. **[Another Dependency]**\n   ...\n\n### Downstream Consumers (What depends on my changes)\n1. **[Component/Module]** at `path/to/consumer.ext:lines`\n   - **What it expects:** [Interface / contract]\n   - **Breaking changes risk:** YES/NO\n   - **Migration needed:** YES/NO\n   - **Verification:** [How to verify integration]\n\n2. **[Another Consumer]**\n   ...\n\n### Shared Interfaces / Contracts\n```markdown\n**Interface 1: [Name]**\n- **Type/Schema:** [Definition]\n- **Used by:** [List of files]\n- **Defined in:** `path/to/types.ext:lines`\n- **Must maintain:** [Compatibility requirements]\n\n**Interface 2: [Name]**\n...\n```\n\n### Database Schema Dependencies\n- **Tables affected:** [table names]\n- **Columns needed:** [column list]\n- **Constraints:** [foreign keys, indexes]\n- **Migration strategy:** [How to handle schema changes]\n\n### API Endpoints Involved\n- **Existing endpoints to modify:**\n  - `METHOD /path` in `file.ext:lines`\n- **New endpoints to create:**\n  - `METHOD /new-path` - [purpose]\n- **Compatibility:** [Breaking changes? Versioning needed?]\n\n### Configuration Dependencies\n- **Environment variables:** [List with purposes]\n- **Config files:** `path/to/config.ext`\n- **Defaults:** [Where to set defaults]\n```\n\n---\n\n### Phase 5: Test Strategy Discovery\n\n**Goal:** Understand how to test following project conventions.\n\n#### 5.1 Test Pattern Analysis\n\n```markdown\n## Test Strategy from Codebase\n\n### Testing Framework Detected\n- **Framework:** [Jest / pytest / go test / JUnit / RSpec / etc.]\n- **Test runner command:** `[actual command from package.json or scripts]`\n- **Config location:** `[jest.config.js / pytest.ini / etc.]`\n\n### Test File Patterns Found\n- **Unit tests:** `__tests__/*.test.ext` or `*.test.ext`\n- **Integration tests:** `__tests__/integration/*.test.ext`\n- **E2E tests:** `__tests__/e2e/*.test.ext` (if exists)\n\n### Test Structure Pattern\n**Found in:** `path/to/example.test.ext`\n\n```[language]\ndescribe('[Component]', () => {\n  // Setup (beforeEach, fixtures)\n\n  describe('[function/method]', () => {\n    it('should [expected behavior]', () => {\n      // Arrange\n      const input = ...\n\n      // Act\n      const result = functionUnderTest(input)\n\n      // Assert\n      expect(result).toBe(...)\n    })\n  })\n})\n```\n\n### Mocking Patterns\n- **Mock location:** `__tests__/__mocks__/`\n- **Mock pattern from:** `path/to/mock-example.ext:lines`\n- **How to mock:**\n  - External APIs: [pattern]\n  - Database: [pattern]\n  - File system: [pattern]\n  - Time/Date: [pattern]\n\n### Test Data / Fixtures\n- **Location:** `__tests__/fixtures/` or `__tests__/mocks/`\n- **Pattern:** [How test data is organized]\n- **Example from:** `path/to/fixture.ext`\n\n### Coverage Expectations\n- **Current project coverage:** [percentage from config or CI]\n- **Coverage command:** `[actual command]`\n- **Minimum required:** [threshold from config]\n```\n\n---\n\n### Phase 6: Risk and Challenge Assessment\n\n**Goal:** Identify potential issues before implementation.\n\n```markdown\n## Risks & Challenges Identified\n\n### Technical Risks\n\n1. **[Risk Name]**\n   - **Description:** [What could go wrong]\n   - **Likelihood:** Low / Medium / High\n   - **Impact:** Low / Medium / High\n   - **Evidence:** [Why you think this is a risk]\n   - **Mitigation:** [How to prevent or handle it]\n   - **Fallback:** [Plan B if mitigation fails]\n\n2. **[Another Risk]**\n   ...\n\n### Complexity Assessment\n- **Overall complexity:** Low / Medium / High\n- **Reasoning:** [Why this complexity level]\n- **Complex areas:**\n  1. [Area]: [Why complex]\n  2. [Area]: [Why complex]\n\n### Missing Information / Ambiguities\n- [ ] **[What's unclear]**\n  - **Context:** [Why this is needed]\n  - **Impact:** [What happens if we don't clarify]\n  - **Recommendation:** [Suggested approach]\n\n### External Dependencies\n- **Third-party packages needed:** [list]\n- **API dependencies:** [external services]\n- **Version constraints:** [compatibility requirements]\n```\n\n---\n\n## ðŸŽ¯ RESEARCH.md Template Output\n\nAfter completing all research phases, generate this structured file:\n\n```markdown\n# Research for [TASK-NAME]\n\n## Context Reference\n**For tech stack and conventions, see:**\n- `path/to/AI_PROMPT.md` - Universal context\n- `path/to/TASK.md` - Task-level context\n- `path/to/PROMPT.md` - Task-specific context\n\n**This file contains ONLY new information discovered during research.**\n\n---\n\n## Task Understanding Summary\n[1-2 sentence summary - reference TODO.md for full details]\n\n---\n\n## Similar Components Found (LEARN FROM THESE)\n\n### 1. [Component Name] - `path/to/similar.ext:lines`\n**Why similar:** [Explanation]\n**Patterns to reuse:**\n- Lines X-Y: [Pattern description]\n- Lines A-B: [Another pattern]\n**Key learnings:**\n- [Learning 1]\n- [Learning 2]\n\n### 2. [Another Component] - `path/to/other.ext:lines`\n...\n\n---\n\n## Reusable Components (USE THESE, DON'T RECREATE)\n\n### 1. [Utility Name] - `path/to/utility.ext`\n**Purpose:** [What it does]\n**How to use:**\n```[language]\nimport { X } from 'path/to/utility';\n// Usage example\nX.method(params);\n```\n**Integration into task:** [How you'll use it]\n\n### 2. [Another Utility] - `path/to/other-utility.ext`\n...\n\n---\n\n## Codebase Conventions Discovered\n\n### File Organization\n- Pattern: [Structure found in reference files]\n- Example: `path/to/example.ext`\n\n### Naming Conventions\n- Files: [convention]\n- Functions: [convention]\n- Classes: [convention]\n- Constants: [convention]\n\n### Error Handling Pattern\n```[language]\n// Pattern from path/to/reference.ext:lines\n[code example]\n```\n\n### Testing Pattern\n```[language]\n// Pattern from path/to/test-example.test.ext:lines\n[code example]\n```\n\n---\n\n## Integration & Impact Analysis\n\n### Functions/Classes/Components Being Modified:\n1. **`functionName`** in `path/to/file.ext:lines`\n   - **Called by:**\n     - `path/to/caller1.ext:line`\n     - `path/to/caller2.ext:line`\n   - **Parameter contract:** `function(param1: type1, param2: type2): returnType`\n   - **Impact:** [How changes affect callers]\n   - **Breaking changes:** YES/NO - [Explanation]\n\n### API/Database/External Integration:\n[Only if applicable]\n- **API endpoints affected:**\n  - `METHOD /path` in `file.ext:lines` - [impact]\n- **Database schema changes:**\n  - Table: [changes needed]\n- **External dependencies:**\n  - [service/library] - [how used]\n\n---\n\n## Test Strategy Discovered\n\n### Testing Framework\n- **Framework:** [Name]\n- **Test command:** `[actual command]`\n- **Config:** `path/to/config`\n\n### Test Patterns Found\n- **Test file location:** [pattern]\n- **Test structure:** [describe-it / def test / etc.]\n- **Example from:** `path/to/example.test.ext:lines`\n\n### Mocking Approach\n- **Mock location:** `path/to/mocks/`\n- **Pattern:** [how to mock]\n- **Example:** `path/to/mock-example.ext:lines`\n\n---\n\n## Risks & Challenges Identified\n\n### Technical Risks\n1. **[Risk]**\n   - Impact: [High/Medium/Low]\n   - Mitigation: [Strategy]\n\n### Complexity Assessment\n- Overall: [Low/Medium/High]\n- Reasoning: [Why]\n\n### Missing Information\n- [ ] [What's unclear and why it matters]\n\n---\n\n## Execution Strategy Recommendation\n\n**Based on research findings, execute in this order:**\n\n1. **[Step 1]** - [Specific action]\n   - Read: `path/to/pattern.ext:lines`\n   - Create/Modify: `path/to/target.ext`\n   - Follow pattern from: [reference]\n   - Test with: `[command]`\n\n2. **[Step 2]** - [Next action]\n   - Reuse component: `path/to/utility.ext`\n   - Integration point: `path/to/integration.ext:lines`\n   - Verify: [how to verify]\n\n3. **[Step 3]** - [Final action]\n   - Follow test pattern: `path/to/test-example.test.ext:lines`\n   - Run: `[test command] path/to/new-test`\n   - Acceptance: [criteria]\n\n---\n\n**Research completed:** [timestamp]\n**Total similar components found:** [number]\n**Total reusable components identified:** [number]\n**Estimated complexity:** [Low/Medium/High]\n```\n\n---\n\n## ðŸš« Anti-Patterns to Avoid in RESEARCH.md\n\nâŒ **Copying context already in AI_PROMPT.md/TASK.md/PROMPT.md**\n- These files already contain tech stack, conventions, etc.\n- RESEARCH.md should only contain NEW discoveries\n\nâœ… **Reference existing context and add new findings**\n- \"See AI_PROMPT.md for tech stack\"\n- \"New pattern found in [file] not mentioned in existing context\"\n\n---\n\nâŒ **Vague pattern references**\n- \"Follow best practices\"\n- \"Similar code exists somewhere\"\n\nâœ… **Specific file:line references**\n- \"Follow pattern in `src/services/user-service.js:45-80`\"\n- \"Reuse validation from `src/utils/validator.js:20`\"\n\n---\n\nâŒ **Not searching for existing solutions**\n- Immediately creating new utilities\n- Reinventing existing patterns\n\nâœ… **Thoroughly search before creating**\n- \"Searched for validation utils - found reusable `validateInput` at `src/utils/validation.js:15`\"\n- \"No similar handler found - will create following pattern from `src/handlers/example.js`\"\n\n---\n\nâŒ **Generic integration analysis**\n- \"Will integrate with other modules\"\n- \"May affect some components\"\n\nâœ… **Specific integration mapping**\n- \"Modifies `getUserData` which is called by 3 components at [specific files:lines]\"\n- \"Breaking change: signature changes from (id) to (id, options)\"\n\n---\n\nâŒ **Shallow test strategy**\n- \"Will write tests\"\n- \"Use Jest\"\n\nâœ… **Detailed test pattern discovery**\n- \"Follow test structure from `__tests__/user-service.test.js:20-80`\"\n- \"Use existing mock helpers from `__tests__/__mocks__/database.js`\"\n\n---\n\n## âœ… Quality Checklist for RESEARCH.md\n\nBefore generating RESEARCH.md, verify:\n\n### Discovery Completeness\n- [ ] Searched for similar components (by name, function, architecture)\n- [ ] Identified all reusable utilities/helpers\n- [ ] Found relevant test patterns\n- [ ] Located integration points\n- [ ] Analyzed conventions from actual code\n\n### Specificity\n- [ ] All references include `file:line` or `file:line-range`\n- [ ] Patterns include concrete code examples\n- [ ] Integration points list specific files/functions\n- [ ] Test strategy references actual test files\n\n### Actionability\n- [ ] Execution strategy is step-by-step\n- [ ] Each step references specific files to read/modify\n- [ ] Clear which components to reuse vs create\n- [ ] Test approach follows project conventions\n\n### No Duplication\n- [ ] References AI_PROMPT.md/TASK.md/PROMPT.md for existing context\n- [ ] Only includes NEW discoveries from research\n- [ ] Doesn't copy tech stack or conventions already documented\n\n---\n\n## ðŸŽ¯ Success Criteria\n\nA high-quality RESEARCH.md should enable the agent to:\n\n1. âœ… **Reuse** existing components instead of creating duplicates\n2. âœ… **Follow** established patterns for consistency\n3. âœ… **Integrate** correctly with existing code\n4. âœ… **Test** using project conventions\n5. âœ… **Execute** efficiently with a clear strategy\n\n**Impact Metrics:**\n- **Code consistency:** 90%+ pattern adherence\n- **Reuse rate:** 70%+ of utilities reused vs created\n- **Integration success:** Cover all specified valid emails, invalid emails, and edge cases.\n\n**Required Test Structure:**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n**Required Valid Email Tests:**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid email\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**Required Invalid Email Tests (minimum):**\n- `@example.com` - no local part\n- `user@` - no domain\n- `user@@example.com` - double @\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots\n\n**Additional Edge Cases to Cover:**\n- Empty string\n- No @ symbol (`userexample.com`)\n- Leading dot in local (`.user@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in local (`user.@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in domain (`user@example.com.`)\n- Consecutive dots in local (`user..name@example.com`)\n- Local part > 64 characters\n- Domain part > 255 characters\n- Space in local part\n- Space in domain\n- Disallowed character in local (`user!@example.com`)\n- Disallowed character in domain (`user@example#.com`)\n- No dot in domain (`user@example`)\n\nAfter implementation, verify with:\n```bash\nuv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\nuv run ruff check test_email_validator.py\nuv run ruff format --check test_email_validator.py\n```\n\n## COMPLEXITY\nLow\n\n## CONTEXT REFERENCE\n**For complete environment context, read:**\n- `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/.claudiomiro/AI_PROMPT.md` - Valid emails (happy path) - should return True\n2. Invalid - structural issues - missing parts, multiple @\n3. Invalid - dot issues - leading, trailing, consecutive\n4. However, for reference:\n\n**Email Validation Pattern (example approach):**\n```python\ndef validate_email(email: str) -> bool:\n    \"\"\"Validate email address according to specified rules.\n\n    Args:\n        email: The email address to validate.\n\n    Returns:\n        True if valid, False otherwise.\n    \"\"\"\n    # Implementation here\n    pass\n```\n\n**Test Pattern (pytest style):**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\ndef test_valid_email_simple():\n    assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\ndef test_invalid_email_no_at():\n    assert validate_email(\"userexample.com\") is False\n```\n\n---\n\n## âœ… Acceptance Criteria\n\n### Core Functionality\n- [ ] Function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` exists in `email_validator.py`\n- [ ] Function returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n- [ ] Function has proper type hints\n\n### Validation Rules (ALL must be enforced)\n- [ ] Exactly one `@` symbol required\n- [ ] Local part (before @) must be 1-64 characters long\n- [ ] Domain part (after @) must be 1-255 characters long\n- [ ] Domain must contain at least one dot (`.`)\n- [ ] No consecutive dots (`..`) allowed anywhere\n- [ ] No leading dot in local part (e.g., `.user@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in local part (e.g., `user.@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No leading dot in domain part (e.g., `user@.example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in domain part (e.g., `user@example.com.` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] Only allowed characters: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n\n### Required Test Cases\n**Must pass (valid emails):**\n- [ ] `user@example.com`\n- [ ] `user.name@domain.co.uk`\n- [ ] `user+tag@example.org`\n\n**Must fail (invalid emails):**\n- [ ] `@example.com` (no local part)\n- [ ] `user@` (no domain)\n- [ ] `user@@example.com` (double @)\n- [ ] `user@.com` (leading dot in domain)\n- [ ] `user@example..com` (consecutive dots)\n\n### Code Quality\n- [ ] Passes `ruff check .` with no errors\n- [ ] Passes `ruff format --check .` with no errors\n- [ ] All pytest tests pass\n- [ ] Code has docstrings explaining the function\n\n---\n\n## âš™ï¸ Implementation Guidance\n\n### Execution Layers\n\n**Layer 0 - Foundation:**\n1. Create `email_validator.py` with the `validate_email` function\n2. Implement all validation rules in order of simplicity\n\n**Layer 1 - Testing:**\n1. Create `test_email_validator.py` with pytest tests\n2. Cover all required valid/invalid cases\n3. Add edge case tests\n\n**Layer 2 - Validation:**\n1. Run `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v`\n2. Run `uv run ruff check .`\n3. Run `uv run ruff format --check .`\n4. Fix any issues\n\n### Implementation Approach\n\n**Recommended validation order (in function):**\n1. Check for exactly one `@` symbol (reject if not)\n2. Split into local and domain parts\n3. Check local part length (1-64)\n4. Check domain part length (1-255)\n5. Check domain has at least one dot\n6. Check no consecutive dots anywhere\n7. Check no leading/trailing dots in local part\n8. Check no leading/trailing dots in domain part\n9. Check all characters are in allowed set\n\n**Character validation:**\n- Allowed in both local and domain: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n- Allowed ONLY in local part: `_`, `%`, `+`\n- The `@` symbol is the separator (already validated)\n\n### Expected Artifacts\n\n| File | Purpose |\n|------|---------|\n| `email_validator.py` | Main module with `validate_email` function |\n| `test_email_validator.py` | Comprehensive pytest test suite |\n\n### Constraints\n- **DO NOT** use external email validation libraries\n- **DO NOT** use `re` module for regex (use string methods for simplicity and clarity)\n- **DO NOT** create additional helper files\n- **DO NOT** over-engineer - keep it simple and readable\n- **DO NOT** add features beyond what's specified\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§ª Testing Guidance\n\n### Test Structure\n```python\n# test_email_validator.py\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n### Required Test Categories\n\n**1. Valid emails (happy path):**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**2. Invalid - structural issues:**\n- `@example.com` - missing local part\n- `user@` - missing domain\n- `user@@example.com` - multiple @ symbols\n- `userexample.com` - no @ symbol\n- Empty string\n\n**3. Invalid - dot issues:**\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `.user@example.com` - leading dot in local\n- `user.@example.com` - trailing dot in local\n- `user@example.com.` - trailing dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots in domain\n- `user..name@example.com` - consecutive dots in local\n\n**4. Invalid - length issues:**\n- Local part > 64 chars\n- Domain part > 255 chars\n- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n\n**5. Invalid - character issues:**\n- `user name@example.com` - space\n- `user@exam ple.com` - space in domain\n- `user!@example.com` - disallowed character\n- `user@example#.com` - disallowed character in domain\n\n**6. Invalid - domain structure:**\n- `user@example` - no dot in domain\n\n### Minimum Test Count\n- At least 3 valid email tests (as specified)\n- At least 5 invalid email tests (as specified)\n- Additional edge case tests recommended\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ” Verification and Traceability\n\n### Pre-Completion Checklist\n\nBefore marking complete, verify:\n\n1. **Files exist:**\n   - [ ] `email_validator.py` created in project root\n   - [ ] `test_email_validator.py` created in project root\n\n2. **Tests pass:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\n   ```\n   - [ ] All tests pass (0 failures)\n\n3. **Linting passes:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run ruff check .\n   uv run ruff format --check .\n   ```\n   - [ ] No ruff errors\n   - [ ] No formatting issues\n\n4. **Manual spot check:**\n   ```python\n   from email_validator import validate_email\n   assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") == True\n   assert validate_email(\"invalid\") == False\n   ```\n\n5. **Git commit:**\n   - The junior implementation uses `re` module (regex) - **BUT our task EXPLICITLY FORBIDS regex**\n2. Pattern: isinstance check first (line 38-39)\n3. Pattern: count('@') != 1 check early (line 42-43)\n4. Pattern: split('@') for local/domain separation (line 46)\n5. Pattern: length validation with chained comparison `1 <= len(x) <= 64` (lines 49, 53)\n6. Lines 82-88: Domain label hyphen validation (start/end) - NOT in our spec, skip this\n\n**Critical difference:** Our task MUST use string methods instead of regex:\n- Replace `local_pattern.fullmatch(local)` with `all(c in LOCAL_ALLOWED for c in local)`\n- Replace `domain_pattern.fullmatch(domain)` with `all(c in DOMAIN_ALLOWED for c in domain)`\n\n### 2. Use `pytest.mark.parametrize` for multiple similar test cases\n2. Use descriptive `ids=` parameter for test identification\n3. Group tests by validation category (structure, dots, length, characters)\n4. Use `is True` / `is False` assertions (not just truthy)\n5. Include type handling tests (None, int, list, dict) - lines 384-401\n6. Include edge cases (whitespace, unicode, tabs, newlines) - lines 404-429\n\n---\n\n## Reusable Components (USE THESE, DON'T RECREATE)\n\n### None found in codebase\nThis is a standalone greenfield project. # Build domain with valid structure: multiple subdomains\n   167â†’        # Using pattern like: aaa.aaa.aaa...aaa.com (255 chars total)\n   168â†’        base = \"a\" * 50\n   169â†’        domain = f\"{base}.{base}.{base}.{base}.com\"\n   170â†’        while len(domain) < 255:\n   171â†’            domain = \"a\" + domain\n   172â†’        domain = domain[:255]\n   173â†’        # Ensure it has at least one dot and valid structure\n   174â†’        domain = \"a\" * 126 + \".\" + \"a\" * 126 + \".ab\"  # 126 + 1 + 126 + 1 + 2 = 255 + 1\n   175â†’        domain = \"a\" * 125 + \".\" + \"a\" * 125 + \".abc\"  # 125 + 1 + 125 + 1 + 3 = 255\n   176â†’        assert len(domain) == 255\n   177â†’        assert validate_email(f\"user@{domain}\") is True\n   178â†’\n   179â†’    def invalid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"userexample.com\") is False\n\n    def test_two_at_invalid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test that two @ symbols is invalid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@exam@ple.com\") is False\n\n    def test_three_at_invalid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test that three @ symbols is invalid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@exam@ple@com\") is False\n\n\nclass TestLocalPartLength:\n    \"\"\"Tests for local part length requirements.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_min_length_valid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test local part with 1 character is valid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"a@example.com\") is True\n\n    def test_max_length_valid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test local part with 64 characters is valid.\"\"\"\n        local = \"a\" * 64\n        assert validate_email(f\"{local}@example.com\") is True\n\n    def test_over_max_length_invalid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test local part with 65 characters is invalid.\"\"\"\n        local = \"a\" * 65\n        assert validate_email(f\"{local}@example.com\") is False\n\n    def test_zero_length_invalid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test empty local part is invalid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n\nclass TestDomainLength:\n    \"\"\"Tests for domain part length requirements.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_min_length_valid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test domain with minimum valid characters.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@a.b\") is True\n\n    def test_max_length_valid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test domain with 255 characters is valid.\"\"\"\n        # Build domain with valid structure: multiple subdomains\n        # Using pattern like: aaa.aaa.aaa...aaa.com (255 chars total)\n        base = \"a\" * 50\n        domain = f\"{base}.{base}.{base}.{base}.com\"\n        while len(domain) < 255:\n            domain = \"a\" + domain\n        domain = domain[:255]\n        # Ensure it has at least one dot and valid structure\n        domain = \"a\" * 126 + \".\" + \"a\" * 126 + \".ab\"  # 126 + 1 + 126 + 1 + 2 = 255 + 1\n        domain = \"a\" * 125 + \".\" + \"a\" * 125 + \".abc\"  # 125 + 1 + 125 + 1 + 3 = 255\n        assert len(domain) == 255\n        assert validate_email(f\"user@{domain}\") is True\n\n    def test_over_max_length_invalid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test domain with 256 characters is invalid.\"\"\"\n        domain = \"a\" * 125 + \".\" + \"a\" * 125 + \".abcd\"  # 256 chars\n        assert len(domain) == 256\n        assert validate_email(f\"user@{domain}\") is False\n\n    def test_zero_length_invalid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test empty domain is invalid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@\") is False\n\n\nclass TestDomainDotRequirement:\n    \"\"\"Tests for domain dot requirement.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_dot_invalid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test domain without dot is invalid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@localhost\") is False\n\n    def test_single_dot_valid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test domain with one dot is valid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    def test_multiple_dots_valid(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test domain with multiple dots is valid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@mail.example.co.uk\") is True\n\n\nclass TestConsecutiveDots:\n    \"\"\"Tests for consecutive dots.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_consecutive_dots_local_invalid(self) -> None:\n non-consecutive dots are valid.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"a.b.c@d.e.f\") is True\n\n\nclass TestLeadingTrailingDots:\n    \"\"\"Tests for leading and trailing dots.\"\"\"\n\n    def Class docstrings explain test category\n5. Separate individual spec tests from parametrized tests (lines 43-53, 94-112)\n\n**Structure pattern from lines 7-54:**\n```python\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    @pytest.mark.parametrize(\n        \"email\",\n        [\"user@example.com\", ...],\n        ids=[\"basic_email\", ...],\n    )\n    def test_valid_email_formats(self, email: str) -> None:\n        assert validate_email(email) is True\n\n    def test_spec_example_valid_1(self) -> None:\n        \"\"\"Test spec example: user@example.com.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n```\n\n**Reuse decision:** Adapt pattern - Rule 1: Exactly one @ symbol\n    if email.count(\"@\") != 1:\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 2: Split into local and domain parts\n    local, domain = email.split(\"@\", 1)\n\n    # Rule 3: Local part must be 1-64 characters\n    if not (1 <= len(local) <= 64):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 4: Domain part must be 1-255 characters\n    if not (1 <= len(domain) <= 255):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 5: Domain must contain at least one dot\n    if \".\" not in domain:\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 6: No consecutive dots anywhere\n    if \"..\" in email:\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 7: No leading dot in local part\n    if local.startswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 8: No trailing dot in local part\n    if local.endswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 9: No leading dot in domain part\n    if domain.startswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 10: No trailing dot in domain part\n    if domain.endswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 11: Only allowed characters\n    if not all(c in LOCAL_ALLOWED for c in local):\n        return False\n\n    if not all(c in DOMAIN_ALLOWED for c in domain):\n        return False\n\n    return True\n","numLines":67,"startLine":1,"totalLines":67}}}

Dot issues\n    def test_leading_dot_in_domain(self):\n        \"\"\"Test email with leading dot in domain.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@.com\") is False\n\n    def test_consecutive_dots_in_domain(self):\n        \"\"\"Test email with consecutive dots in domain.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example..com\") is False\n\n    def test_leading_dot_in_local(self):\n        \"\"\"Test email with leading dot in local part.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\".user@example.com\") is False\n\n    def test_trailing_dot_in_local(self):\n        \"\"\"Test email with trailing dot in local part.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user.@example.com\") is False\n\n    def test_trailing_dot_in_domain(self):\n        \"\"\"Test email with trailing dot in domain.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com.\") is False\n\n    def test_consecutive_dots_in_local(self):\n        \"\"\"Test email with consecutive dots in local part.\"\"\"\n        assert validate_email(\"user..name@example.com\") is False\n\n    # Length issues\n    def test_local_too_long(self):\n        \"\"\"Test email with local part exceeding 64 characters.\"\"\"\n        long_local = \"a\" * 65 + \"@example.com\"\n        assert validate_email(long_local) is False\n\n    def test_domain_too_long(self):\n        \"\"\"Test email with domain exceeding 255 characters.\"\"\"\n        long_domain = \"user@\" + \"a\" * 252 + \".com\"\n        assert validate_email(long_domain) is False\n\n    # Cover all specified valid emails, invalid emails, and edge cases.\n\n**Required Test Structure:**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n**Required Valid Email Tests:**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid email\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**Required Invalid Email Tests (minimum):**\n- `@example.com` - no local part\n- `user@` - no domain\n- `user@@example.com` - double @\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots\n\n**Additional Edge Cases to Cover:**\n- Empty string\n- No @ symbol (`userexample.com`)\n- Leading dot in local (`.user@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in local (`user.@example.com`)\n- Trailing dot in domain (`user@example.com.`)\n- Consecutive dots in local (`user..name@example.com`)\n- Local part > 64 characters\n- Domain part > 255 characters\n- Space in local part\n- Space in domain\n- Disallowed character in local (`user!@example.com`)\n- Disallowed character in domain (`user@example#.com`)\n- No dot in domain (`user@example`)\n\nAfter implementation, verify with:\n```bash\nuv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\nuv run ruff check test_email_validator.py\nuv run ruff format --check test_email_validator.py\n```\n\n## COMPLEXITY\nLow\n\n## CONTEXT REFERENCE\n**For complete environment context, read:**\n- `/Users/administrator/projects/claude-quickstarts/autonomous-coding/benchmarks/results/claudiomiro/t1_email_validator/.claudiomiro/AI_PROMPT.md` - False |\n\n## Impact Analysis\n- **Directly impacted:**\n  - `test_email_validator.py` (new file)\n\n- **Indirectly impacted:**\n  - TASKÎ© depends on this task completing successfully\n  - Must have Invalid - length issues:**\n   219â†’- Local part > 64 chars\n   220â†’- Domain part > 255 chars\n   221â†’- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n   222â†’- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n   223â†’\n   224â†’**5. However, for reference:\n\n**Email Validation Pattern (example approach):**\n```python\ndef validate_email(email: str) -> bool:\n    \"\"\"Validate email address according to specified rules.\n\n    Args:\n        email: The email address to validate.\n\n    Returns:\n        True if valid, False otherwise.\n    \"\"\"\n    # Implementation here\n    pass\n```\n\n**Test Pattern (pytest style):**\n```python\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\ndef test_valid_email_simple():\n    assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\ndef test_invalid_email_no_at():\n    assert validate_email(\"userexample.com\") is False\n```\n\n---\n\n## âœ… Acceptance Criteria\n\n### Core Functionality\n- [ ] Function `validate_email(email: str) -> bool` exists in `email_validator.py`\n- [ ] Function returns `True` for valid emails, `False` for invalid\n- [ ] Function has proper type hints\n\n### Validation Rules (ALL must be enforced)\n- [ ] Exactly one `@` symbol required\n- [ ] Local part (before @) must be 1-64 characters long\n- [ ] Domain part (after @) must be 1-255 characters long\n- [ ] Domain must contain at least one dot (`.`)\n- [ ] No consecutive dots (`..`) allowed anywhere\n- [ ] No leading dot in local part (e.g., `.user@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in local part (e.g., `user.@example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No leading dot in domain part (e.g., `user@.example.com` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] No trailing dot in domain part (e.g., `user@example.com.` â†’ invalid)\n- [ ] Only allowed characters: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `_`, `%`, `+`, `-`\n\n### Required Test Cases\n**Must pass (valid emails):**\n- [ ] `user@example.com`\n- [ ] `user.name@domain.co.uk`\n- [ ] `user+tag@example.org`\n\n**Must fail (invalid emails):**\n- [ ] `@example.com` (no local part)\n- [ ] `user@` (no domain)\n- [ ] `user@@example.com` (double @)\n- [ ] `user@.com` (leading dot in domain)\n- [ ] `user@example..com` (consecutive dots)\n\n### Code Quality\n- [ ] Passes `ruff check .` with no errors\n- [ ] Passes `ruff format --check .` with no errors\n- [ ] All pytest tests pass\n- [ ] Code has docstrings explaining the function\n\n---\n\n## âš™ï¸ Implementation Guidance\n\n### Execution Layers\n\n**Layer 0 - Foundation:**\n1. Create `email_validator.py` with the `validate_email` function\n2. Implement all validation rules in order of simplicity\n\n**Layer 1 - Testing:**\n1. Create `test_email_validator.py` with pytest tests\n2. Cover all required valid/invalid cases\n3. Add edge case tests\n\n**Layer 2 - Validation:**\n1. Run `uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v`\n2. Run `uv run ruff check .`\n3. Run `uv run ruff format --check .`\n4. Fix any issues\n\n### Implementation Approach\n\n**Recommended validation order (in function):**\n1. Check for exactly one `@` symbol (reject if not)\n2. Split into local and domain parts\n3. Check local part length (1-64)\n4. Check domain part length (1-255)\n5. Check domain has at least one dot\n6. Check no consecutive dots anywhere\n7. Check no leading/trailing dots in local part\n8. Check no leading/trailing dots in domain part\n9. Check all characters are in allowed set\n\n**Character validation:**\n- Allowed in both local and domain: `a-z`, `A-Z`, `0-9`, `.`, `-`\n- Allowed ONLY in local part: `_`, `%`, `+`\n- The `@` symbol is the separator (already validated)\n\n### Expected Artifacts\n\n| File | Purpose |\n|------|---------|\n| `email_validator.py` | Main module with `validate_email` function |\n| `test_email_validator.py` | Comprehensive pytest test suite |\n\n### Constraints\n- **DO NOT** use external email validation libraries\n- **DO NOT** use `re` module for regex (use string methods for simplicity and clarity)\n- **DO NOT** create additional helper files\n- **DO NOT** over-engineer - keep it simple and readable\n- **DO NOT** add features beyond what's specified\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ§ª Testing Guidance\n\n### Test Structure\n```python\n# test_email_validator.py\nimport pytest\nfrom email_validator import validate_email\n\nclass TestValidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be valid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_simple_email(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") is True\n\n    # ... more valid cases\n\nclass TestInvalidEmails:\n    \"\"\"Tests for emails that should be invalid.\"\"\"\n\n    def test_no_local_part(self):\n        assert validate_email(\"@example.com\") is False\n\n    # ... more invalid cases\n```\n\n### Required Test Categories\n\n**1. Valid emails (happy path):**\n- `user@example.com` - basic valid\n- `user.name@domain.co.uk` - dots in local and multi-part domain\n- `user+tag@example.org` - plus sign in local part\n\n**2. Invalid - structural issues:**\n- `@example.com` - missing local part\n- `user@` - missing domain\n- `user@@example.com` - multiple @ symbols\n- `userexample.com` - no @ symbol\n- Empty string\n\n**3. Invalid - dot issues:**\n- `user@.com` - leading dot in domain\n- `.user@example.com` - leading dot in local\n- `user.@example.com` - trailing dot in local\n- `user@example.com.` - trailing dot in domain\n- `user@example..com` - consecutive dots in domain\n- `user..name@example.com` - consecutive dots in local\n\n**4. Invalid - length issues:**\n- Local part > 64 chars\n- Domain part > 255 chars\n- Empty local part (just `@domain.com`)\n- Empty domain part (just `user@`)\n\n**5. Invalid - character issues:**\n- `user name@example.com` - space\n- `user@exam ple.com` - space in domain\n- `user!@example.com` - disallowed character\n- `user@example#.com` - disallowed character in domain\n\n**6. Invalid - domain structure:**\n- `user@example` - no dot in domain\n\n### Minimum Test Count\n- At least 3 valid email tests (as specified)\n- At least 5 invalid email tests (as specified)\n- Additional edge case tests recommended\n\n---\n\n## ðŸ” Verification and Traceability\n\n### Pre-Completion Checklist\n\nBefore marking complete, verify:\n\n1. **Files exist:**\n   - [ ] `email_validator.py` created in project root\n   - [ ] `test_email_validator.py` created in project root\n\n2. **Tests pass:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run pytest test_email_validator.py -v\n   ```\n   - [ ] All tests pass (0 failures)\n\n3. **Linting passes:**\n   ```bash\n   uv run ruff check .\n   uv run ruff format --check .\n   ```\n   - [ ] No ruff errors\n   - [ ] No formatting issues\n\n4. **Manual spot check:**\n   ```python\n   from email_validator import validate_email\n   assert validate_email(\"user@example.com\") == True\n   assert validate_email(\"invalid\") == False\n   ```\n\n5. **Git commit:**\n   - {"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_01KHXQ2WkQzva4zQpaeXB8jE","type":"tool_result","content":"     1â†’\"\"\"Email validator module.\n     2â†’\n     3â†’Provides email validation using only Python stdlib, no regex.\n     4â†’\"\"\"\n     5â†’\n     6â†’# Character sets for validation\n     7â†’LOCAL_ALLOWED = set(\"abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789._%-+\")\n     8â†’DOMAIN_ALLOWED = set(\"abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789.-\")\n     9â†’\n    10â†’\n    11â†’def validate_email(email: str) -> bool:\n    12â†’    \"\"\"Validate email address according to specified rules.\n    13â†’\n    14â†’    Args:\n    15â†’        email: The email address to validate.\n    16â†’\n    17â†’    Returns:\n    18â†’        True if valid, False otherwise.\n    19â†’    \"\"\"\n    20â†’    # Rule 1: Exactly one @ symbol\n    21â†’    if email.count(\"@\") != 1:\n    22â†’        return False\n    23â†’\n    24â†’    # Rule 2: Split into local and domain parts\n    25â†’    local, domain = email.split(\"@\", 1)\n    26â†’\n    27â†’    # Rule 3: Local part must be 1-64 characters\n    28â†’    if not (1 <= len(local) <= 64):\n    29â†’        return False\n    30â†’\n    31â†’    # Rule 4: Domain part must be 1-255 characters\n    32â†’    if not (1 <= len(domain) <= 255):\n    33â†’        return False\n    34â†’\n    35â†’    # Rule 5: Domain must contain at least one dot\n    36â†’    if \".\" not in domain:\n    37â†’        return False\n    38â†’\n    39â†’    # Rule 6: No consecutive dots anywhere\n    40â†’    if \"..\" in email:\n    41â†’        return False\n    42â†’\n    43â†’    # Rule 7: No leading dot in local part\n    44â†’    if local.startswith(\".\"):\n    45â†’        return False\n    46â†’\n    47â†’    # Rule 8: No trailing dot in local part\n    48â†’    if local.endswith(\".\"):\n    49â†’        return False\n    50â†’\n    51â†’    # Rule 9: No leading dot in domain part\n    52â†’    if domain.startswith(\".\"):\n    53â†’        return False\n    54â†’\n    55â†’    # Rule 10: No trailing dot in domain part\n    56â†’    if domain.endswith(\".\"):\n    57â†’        return False\n    58â†’\n    59â†’    # Rule 1: Exactly one @ symbol\n    if email.count(\"@\") != 1:\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 2: Split into local and domain parts\n    local, domain = email.split(\"@\", 1)\n\n    # Rule 3: Local part must be 1-64 characters\n    if not (1 <= len(local) <= 64):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 4: Domain part must be 1-255 characters\n    if not (1 <= len(domain) <= 255):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 5: Domain must contain at least one dot\n    if \".\" not in domain:\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 6: No consecutive dots anywhere\n    if \"..\" in email:\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 7: No leading dot in local part\n    if local.startswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 8: No trailing dot in local part\n    if local.endswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 9: No leading dot in domain part\n    if domain.startswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 10: No trailing dot in domain part\n    if domain.endswith(\".\"):\n        return False\n\n    # Rule 11: Only allowed characters\n    if not all(c in LOCAL_ALLOWED for c in local):\n        return False\n\n    if not all(c in DOMAIN_ALLOWED for c in domain):\n        return False\n\n    return True\n","numLines":67,"startLine":1,"totalLines":67}}}
